loans.name: Barbara

texts.en:
Barbara is a 45-year-old single mother of four children, of whom the eldest is 20 years. All her children go to school and she doesn’t take care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she is staying with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Barbara has a stall selling bananas in Kalerwe market. She doesn’t incur transport costs to and from buying bananas as she buys from her place of work from delivery trucks which bring them from the villages. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works six days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, retail and wholesale.

Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and monthly market dues for her business and school fees for her children and rent. Her major business challenges are the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching out to her because she works in muddy place.

Barbara has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for thirteen years, servicing her twenty-sixth loan, working with the same group mates. Barbara joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.She is aspiring of seeing her business grower bigger and of going to farmers directly.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Mrs. Tim S., 29, is a cake seller who, since early 2007, has been operating her business located in Kompong Tom province. She buys her ingredient on credit to make cakes and pays after she finishes selling. She is able to generate $2 each day to support the requirements of her family.

Another source of family income comes from her husband’s job. He is a carpenter and he is shown in the photo. Due to her husband needing supplies to perform his enterprise, Tim S. is applying for a loan to buy carpentry materials.

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials for her husband's business

loans.name: Ulduza

texts.en: Ulduza B. is married and has 4 children. She is 45 years old. Ulduza is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, but is now settled in Absheron town, Masazir village. She has been in her business for 8 years. Now she needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy 15 sheep.

loans.use: to buy 15 sheep

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana D. is from the village of Libertad Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old. Ana is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Ana owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Ana has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Ana is requesting a new loan of 9,500 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Sinat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinat C. is 41 years old and she is the village bank president of this group of sixteen people located in Chamrov village, Takeo province. Each member of the group will use the loan to support their family in a different way, and they all hope that the loan will help them to improve their family living.

Mrs. Sinat C. is a silk weaver. Since her business still provides less income than needed to support her family, she wants to expand it. So she decided to ask for 400,000 KHR from AMK to buy more silks to increase her income and improve her family’s standard of living.

Mrs. Sinat C. is the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory and the other is too young to study or work. Her husband, Mr. Khen Khem, is a laborer in Thai who is able to earn a low salary to support the family.

loans.use: To buy more silks for her weaving business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 30 year widow with three children between 5 and 10 years of age.  She rents a one room house where she is staying with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets two meals a day. 

Sarah has a poultry farm in Kawempe Bubajjwe.  She incurs transport costs when buying chicken feed from the Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.  Sarah works seven days a week .She receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are the rainy season which prevents her customers from reaching her because she works in a muddy place. 

Sarah has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for thirteen years, servicing her twenty sixth loan. Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feed and chicks. Sarah hopes to see her business grow bigger and to eventually own 1000 chicks.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Myline

texts.en:
Myline A. is from the village of Taboo,Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old. Myline is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Myline owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Myline has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myline joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myline is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Doru

texts.en:
Doru R. is currently in the business of selling beans, rice  and Sim Sim (sesame seed) at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell.  Doru is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a policeman. They have 5 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan,Doru hopes to be able to open a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah N. is a 29 year old married mother of four children between 3 and 10 years of age. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Faridah owns a four room house. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  

Faridah has a used clothing stall in Kawala. She incurs transport costs buying second hand clothes from the Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works five days a week. Faridah receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. Besides the clothing business ,she also sells raw food.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, monthly market dues for her business and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation of bales of clothes. 

Faridah has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for four years servicing her eighth loan, working with the same group mates. Faridah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. In the future, Faridah hopes to see her business grow and to start exporting clothes directly.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Chanthol's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthol N. is 31 years old. She is a village bank president. Her group consists of 14 people, located in Chamrov village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nget Hien, are farmers who own piece of land on which they cultivate rice. Aside from farming, Mrs. Chanthol N. weaves silk  to earn a living. She wants to expand her silk weaving business so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk. Mrs. Chanthol N. and her husband have a child who is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave.

loans.name: Okwir

texts.en:
S. Okwir is 29 years old and is married.  Her husbanc is a taxi driver. They have 1 child who does yet go to school. S. is currently in the business of selling cassava flour in the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of cassava flour to sell.   With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a beauty saloon.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of posho and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Gidah

texts.en:
Gidah N. is a 38 year old married mother of three children between 15 and 20 years of age . All her children go to school and she takes care of additional family members. She owns a four room house where she lives with her family.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  

Gidah has a beauty salon in Kawaala where she works on all types  of hair;  relaxing, weaving and plaiting. She incurs transport costs buying cosmetics and creams from shops on Luwum street. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week. Gidah sees an average of 10 customers a day.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and monthly market dues for her business and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation of boxes of creams. 

Gidah has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for three years servicing her sixth loan. Gidah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of creams. She hopes to see her business grow and to start a bridal salon.

loans.use: To buy more creams and hair relaxers and extensions

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
S. is 29 years old and lives with another family member in Kompong Tom Province. She has built a stall next to her house where she feeds animals to earn a living. She breeds animals such as pigs, ducks and chickens, which she sells to buyers when they are mature. S. conducts her trade very well because she knows how to raise pigs well. In order to make additional income, she is requesting a loan of $600 USD to buy small pigs, ducks, and chickens to breed.
S. is married to Cheng Oul, aged 30, who assists her in raising the animals. The couple do not have children.

loans.use: To buy small pigs, ducks and chickens to breed

loans.name: Valerie

texts.en:
Valerie is 42 years old and is married with four children with ages between 4 and 12 years. Valerie and her family live in Nyamagabe, in the Southern Province of Rwanda.

Valerie has been in the business of studio photography for the past ten years and she is still in the same profession. Her studio is open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day. She employs two people in her studio and she hopes to see her studio become extremely expanded.

Valerie says her goal is to expand her studio through purchasing some additional equipment including a machine to be used in printing out the photos. She is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can achieve this goal.

If her plan is successful, Valerie hopes to build a secure future for her family as well as reinvesting some of her earned profits in the business.

loans.use: To buy some additional equipment including a machine to be used in printing out the photos

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane M. is a 38 year old single mother of five children between 15 and 23 years of age. She resides and owns a four room house where she lives with her family.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  

Jane sells second hand clothes in the Kawempe market. She incurs transport costs buying clothes from the Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.  Jane works six days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, monthly market dues for her business and school fees for her children. Jane's major business challenge is the transportation of bales of clothes from the Owino market to her business premises. 

Jane has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for six years servicing her twelfth loan. Jane joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of cloth.  She hopes to see her business grow so that she can start selling to only wholesale customers.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Nelma

texts.en:
Nelma Y. is from the village of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental.  She is 55 years old, married and has 2 adult-age children. To make a living, Nelma owns & operates a tailoring business.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from sewing and the rental of gowns to the local community. Nelma has been engaged in her business for 11 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to provide additional capital for the needs of her tailoring business. Nelma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nelma from PMPC and the 2nd one to be funded by Kiva. Nelma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital and to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles S. is a 40 year old business man. He is married with three children. Charles is a trader who deals with utensils. He has been in this business for over 3 years. Charles is asking for a loan to purchase home utensils such as basins, cups, plates, spoons, forks, knives, frying pan, sauce pans, flasks, clocks, and so forth for sale. His aim is to expand his business. Charles's future plan is to open up another branch. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

loans.use: To purchase home utensils for for sale.

loans.name: Teo

texts.en: Teo is a 50 year single mother of four children aged between 15 and 21 years. She resides and owns a four-room house where she is staying with four people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. Teo sells bananas in Kawempe market. She incurs transport costs to and from buying matooke (bananas) from villages in Uganda. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works six days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people in retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, monthly market dues for her business, and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation of bananas and theft. Teo has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for seven years. This is her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. Teo joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: Purchase more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy K. is a businesswoman. She is 45 years old. She owns a retail shop and has worked in this business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as soap, rice, maize flour, sugar, sweets, bread, drinks like soda, milk, water, and so forth to meet her clients’ demands. Her future dream is expanding her shop to wholesale.

loans.use: Purchase retail items such as soap, rice, maize flour, sugar, sweets, bread, drinks like soda, milk, water, etc.

loans.name: Liwayway

texts.en:
Liwayway T. is a native of Morong, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a 72-year-old widow surviving on her own. At her age, Liwayway is seen as a strong, old woman determined to raise her standard of living.

In 2004, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI [micro-finance institution] and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She has utilized the loans in her farming business. Since she became a member of ASHI, she has been able to maintain a very good performance. She is now requesting a loan for 30,000 Philippine pesos to use as additional capital for her business.

She still dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own and save for her future because she is getting older now.

loans.use: Additional capital for farming business

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji M. is currently in the business of selling sorghum in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of sorghum to sell. Keji is 39 years old and married to a businessman. She has six children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: Purchase bags of sorghum to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 30 years old and married with four children aged between 6 and 17 years. She resides in and owns a five-room house where she is staying with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. Grace deals in second-hand clothes. She incurs transport costs to and from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works in a semi-urban area which on the outskirts of Kampala. She works six days a week. She receives an average of 15 customers a day and sells to all categories of people in retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, rent for her business location, and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation of second-hand clothes and theft. Grace has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for five years. This is her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. Grace joined MCDT because it was near her home and works with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: Purchase bales of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 28 years-old and married with no children. She resides in a rented one room house where she stays with five people. Sarah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

Sarah is a tailor in Makerere Kikoni zone.  She sews all types of clothes and knits sweaters. She incurs transport costs from shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala City. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works six days a week, receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses are feeding her family and accommodation. Her major business challenges are transportation of clothing materials and defaulters. Sarah has been in this business for ten years and with Kiva partner MCDT for two years and is now servicing her fourth loan, working with the same group mates.  Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more cloth and thread.  She hopes to see her business grow bigger so she can sell only wholesale  and start a tailoring school.

loans.use: To buy cloth and thread.

loans.name: Taban

texts.en:
Taban M. is in the business of selling groundnut paste and onions in the market and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts and onions to sell. Taban is 33 years-old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has eight children and her children go to school. With the extra profits generated by her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase groundnuts and onions.

loans.name: Mang

texts.en:
Mang S. is 36 years old, and is a good mother blessed with five children. Her two grown daughters work in a garment factory while other three go to school. Her husband is a palm climber who taps palm juice and turns it into sugar for sale.
Mang S. stays at home to make Khmer noodles. She also takes the noodles to retail sellers at the market. In order to make her business more successful and earn additional income, Mang S. is requesting a loan to increase the capital of her noodle-producing business. She intends to use the rest of the loan to buy an old motorbike for travel purposes.
Note: Mang S. was not available for a photograph so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: As capital for her noodle-producing business

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 29 years-old and married with six children aged one 1/2 to nine years-old. Four of her children go to school.  She is a mother of twins which are one 1/2 years-old. She resides and rents a one-room house where she stays with five people. Justine also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

Justine sells bananas in Kalerwe Market. She doesn’t incur transport costs because she buys from her place of work. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week, receives an average of 20 customers per day and sells both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses are feeding the family, school fees for her children and rent. Her major business challenge is the rainy season which hinders her customers reaching her as she works from a muddy place. Justine has been in this business for seven years and with Kiva partner MCDT for six years servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates.  Justine joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start selling only wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase banana bunches.

loans.name: Laziya

texts.en: N. Laziya is a successful businesswoman. She is 40 years-old and married with five children in school. She owns a retail shop which she has been running for over two years. She is using the loan to increase the stock of her business by purchasing items such as dishes, forks, knives, frying pans, sauce pans, flasks, basins, cups, plates, spoons, Jeri cans, etc. for sale. Her future plan is to construct a house.

loans.use: To increase her business stock.

loans.name: Gire

texts.en:
Gire V. is in the business of selling groundnuts and charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell.  Gire is 40 years-old and a widow.   She has seven children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and establish a charcoal store.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en: Wilfreda M. is from the village of Owaon. She is 48 years old. Wilfreda is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Wilfreda manufactures and sells iron products to local businesses and community members. Wilfreda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2006, Wilfreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilfreda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Wilfreda is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to pay the tuition fees of her children. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Wilfreda from PMPC and this is her second time with Kiva. She wishes that someday her children can gain degrees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay tuition fees

loans.name: Annette

texts.en:
Annette is a 40-year-old married mother of six children between the ages of 6 and 15. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house, where she is staying with seven people. Annette takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She doesn’t incur transport costs because she buys from her place of work. She works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail and wholesale basis.  

Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her, as she works from a muddy place. Annette has been in this business for 15 years and with MCDT for six years, servicing her 10th loan and working with the same group mates. Annette joined MCDT, a Kiva partner, because it was near her home and was working with poor women. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of alcohol. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start selling on a wholesale basis only.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Yasamen

texts.en:
Yasamen S. is a 43-year-old hardworking mother of four children. She sells poultry in the small village of Agsu and has 12 years of experience in this field. Having been in this business for quite a long time, Yasamen has lots of customers, mainly restaurants owners who buy turkey and geese from her. She gets up at 5 a.m. and works hard, looking after the poultry, until late at night. This is why she is in high demand among her clientele.
Now she is requesting a loan of 1280 AZN to purchase more poultry in order to increase her profit and save money for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry

loans.name: Noverita

texts.en: N. Noverita, 40, is a successful businesswoman. She is married with two children. She has owned a retail shop for two years so far. She is using the loan to purchase retail items, such as rice, sugar, flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, eggs, soap, bread and so forth, for sale. She is aiming at expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items, such as rice, sugar, flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, eggs, soap, bread and so forth, for sale.

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and paste at home and is requesting a loan to buy more groundnuts to make paste to sell.  Poni is 40 years old and is widowed. She has five children; her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Hak

texts.en:
Hak V., age 31, is married with four teenage children, two of whom are employed working in construction while the other two attend school and also do housework.

Hak V. is a local grower who owns a large farmland where she cultivates crops. Her husband works with her in the farming business. Usually the couple generates around $3 of profit a day to meet the needs of their family.

Hak V. faces a problem with plowing her farmland since she doesn’t own a cow. Because of that, she decided to seek a loan to buy a couple of cows to raise for plowing her land and to raise calves.

loans.use: To buy a couple of cows to raise

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Salima, 38, is married with five children between the ages of 3 and 10 years old. All her children go to school. She resides in, and owns, a one-room house where she is staying with seven people. Salima takes care of additional family members, too. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

Salima incurs transport costs to and from buying merchandise from Kikuubo shops, one of the busiest places in Kampala city. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells at retail prices to all categories of people. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenge is transportation during the rainy season, which hinders her customers being able to reach her as she works from a muddy place. 

Salima has been in this business for 15 years and with MCDT for six years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. Salima joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of soap, cartons of salt and bags of sugar. She aspires to see her business grow and to be able to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of soap, cartons of salt and bags of sugar

loans.name: Lugo

texts.en:
C., 41, is married with five children between the ages of 13 and 20 years old. All her children go to school. She resides in, and owns, a one-room house where she is staying with four people. C. takes care of additional family members as well. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

C. incurs transport costs to and from buying food and charcoal from villages of Mubende district. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, on retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenge is transportation during the rainy season, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her. 

C. has been in this business for 20 years and with MCDT for six years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. C. joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal and bunches of bananas, cassava and potatoes. She aspires to see her business grow and to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal, as well as bunches of bananas, cassava and potatoes for resale

loans.name: Cecelia Villalon's Group

texts.en:
Cecelia V. is from the village of Lower Lamac. She is 52 years old. Cecelia is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cecelia is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Cecelia owns and operates a "lapida" (epitaph) making business, providing epitaph services to local community members. Cecelia has been in business for more than ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.In 2004, Cecelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Cecelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide epitaph service

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita G. is from the village of Lapasan, Cagayan de oro City. She is 47 years old. Purita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Purita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Purita has been in business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Purita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Purita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Purita is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to further invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Purita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Estela Toliao's Group

texts.en:
Estela T. is from the village of Lobogon. She is 33 years old. Estela is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Estela is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Estela owns and operates a fish vending business, selling fish in the local community. Estela has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Estela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estela has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Estela is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Estela from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lylin

texts.en:
Lylin C. is a business-minded woman. She and her husband have been blessed with one daughter and one son, both of whom look to her for her support. She lives in Morong, in the province of Rizal, Philippines. She belongs to a poor family who needs help to change their standard of living and to be able to pursue their family dreams.

With her belief in getting out of poverty, she decided in 2007 to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with start-up capital for generating income. During her previous loans from ASHI, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store (a small retail store selling different goods). The income is what she uses for daily expenses.

Now on her fourth loan, Lylin requests 20,000 PHP to create a broader business. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase 16 sacks of rice and groceries for her store. She is very determined and disciplined to use the funds that are lent to her. 

During her almost three years in ASHI, she has shown herself to be hard-working and has strong beliefs to make her dreams come true. She would love to have her own durable and concrete house someday. Lylin C. still dreams of the best for her family: to provide the best education for her children and to have a happy family. She is grateful to ASHI-Kiva partner for support, even in all of her dreams and the challenges in life.

loans.use: To pay for 16 sacks of rice and groceries for her store

loans.name: Janifa

texts.en:
Janifa M. is currently in the business of selling sugar in her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar to sell. Janifa is 32-years-old and is married to a businessman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar to sell

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:
Alphonsine is 25 years old and doesn’t yet have a child as she is still young in marriage. She and her devoted husband live in Nyaruguru, in the Southern Province of Rwanda.

Alphonsine owns a shop selling a variety of goods including some cosmetic goods, foodstuffs like sugar and cooking oil and some soft drinks. This is her 3rd successful year in this business and her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. everyday.

Although Alphonsine has been in the business since 2007, her profit is still too low to expand meaningfully and she believes that a small amount of additional capital would change that for her. For that reason, she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase some additional goods such as Irish potatoes, rice, corn flour, salt, etc.

With these additional goods for sale, Alphonsine hopes to earn more profits, which in turn will help her and her devoted husband to build a secure future for their family.

loans.use: To buy additional goods such as Irish potatoes, rice, corn flour, etc.

loans.name: Marlyna

texts.en:
Marlyna B. is from the village of Gitagum, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Marlyna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marlyna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marlyna has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Marlyna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlyna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marlyna is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marlyna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Uk

texts.en:
Uk R. is an older woman and the mother of four children. Three of her children are married and have already started new homes, while the other one still lives with her and works at fishing. Uk R. was married but her husband died of senility years ago.

To earn her a living, Uk R. earns $2 per day selling traditional medicine that she buys from people living in the forest. She needs a loan to enlarge her enterprise by increasing the quantity of her medicine to sell.

loans.use: To enlarge her enterprise

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a 38-year-old married businesswoman. She owns a retail shop selling essential home products. She has been running her business for more than three years. She will use the loan to purchase retail items, such as sugar, salt, soap, rice, flour and cooking oil, for business expansion. Her future hope is to buy a plot of land and to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items in order to expand her business

loans.name: Alayo

texts.en:
Alayo M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Alayo is 38 years old and is married to a security guard. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Seymur

texts.en:
Seymur F. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two adorable daughters.

Seymur has been breeding cattle for seven years and is trying to improve the breed in order to increase his prices. He invests time and money in the feed and medicines that the animals require. He keeps going, thanks to the help and enthusiasm of his children and his wife, who also help him care for the animals.

Now, Seymur needs a loan of 1,600 AZN to purchase more calves to expand his business. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Benkelema Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  membres du groupe Benkelema de l’association Jiguisseme sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec  en moyenne  44 ans et 4 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quinzième  prêt.  Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font  comme activités la vente  de condiments alimentaires, d’articles de boutique,  la production et la vente de pâte d’arachide, de gâteaux  etc.    
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 5 paquets de condiments, 250kg de graine d’arachide (pour en faire la pâte d’arachide), 1sac de farine, 100kg de sucre, 30litres d’huile, 3 colis d’articles divers (pour la boutique).  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Kadiolo, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  devenir des grossistes.
texts.en:
The five members of the Benkelema group within the Jiguisseme association are essentially married women 44 years old on average, with an average of four children. Most live in polygamous families in Koko - one of Kadiolo’s neighbourhoods - in the third administrative region of Mali. They cooperate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customer’s needs, and have been granted 15 loans to date. All preceding loans were fully reimbursed. Their activities range from the sale of food condiments and grocery items to making and selling peanut butter, cakes, etc. With their new loan, they want to buy: • five packs of condiments • 250 kilos of peanuts (to make peanut butter) • one bag of flour • 100 kilos of sugar • 30 litres of oil • three boxes of various items (for the shop) They get their supplies from the market in Kadiolo and from nearby villages. They sell either in the Kadiolo market, as itinerant retailers, or from their home. They are paid directly or quite often on credit, from a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach individual monthly earnings of 30,500 FCFA on average, part of which will be used for savings and family expenses, and the remainder reinvested in the business activities. They would like to have more working capital to better satisfy their customers and become wholesalers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married and has five children who are all currently in school. She is 48 years old and lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. 

Margaret works hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells on a table top by the road in her community. Margaret buys her raw materials from nearby towns. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and ingredients in bulk to make stew for sale

loans.name: Damou Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe  Damou sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne 42 ans  et 5 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt. Les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font comme activités la vente  des condiments, de Sounbala, la restauration etc.  
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 paquets de condiments, 150kg de graines de néré pour faire le Sounbala, 50kg de graines d’haricots, 50kg de riz, 100kg d’atiécké, 10 litres d’huile (pour la restauration). Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché  de Kadiolo, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  aménager leur point de vente.
texts.en:
The five members of the Damou group are essentially married women 42 years old on average, with an average of five children. Most live in polygamous families in Koko - one of Kadiolo’s neighbourhoods - in the third administrative region of Mali. They cooperate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customer’s needs, and have been granted three loans to date. The preceding loans were fully reimbursed. Their activities are selling food condiments (among which Sounbala), catering, etc. With their new loan, they want to buy: • three packages of condiments • 150 kilos of néré seeds to make Sounbala • 50 kilos of bean seeds • 50 kilos of rice • 100 kilos of atiécké (manioc-based foodstuff) • 10 litres of oil (for catering) They get their supplies from the market in Kadiolo and from nearby villages. They sell either in the Kadiolo market, as itinerant retailers, or from their home. They are paid directly or quite often on credit, from a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach individual monthly earnings of 25,500 FCFA on average, part of which will be used for savings and family expenses, and the remainder reinvested in the business activities. They would like to have more working capital to better satisfy their customers and properly set up their sales outlet.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is a business man. He is 30 years old, married, and the father of two children. He owns a timber business, and he has been in this business for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase and stock timber for customers’ orders. His future desire is to educate his children and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase and stock timber

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is divorced and has four children who are all currently in school. She is 40 years old and lives with her children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. Sarah works very hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. Sarah sells the food on a table top by the side of the road in her community. She buys her raw materials from nearby towns. Sarah has been in business for over 20 years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and ingredients in bulk to make stew for sale

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao K. is years of age and lives in the province of Kampong Chhnang, in Cambodia. She earns a living cultivating a rice crop which she is able to plant twice a year.

Sao K. is a widow and is blessed with four children of whom two are married and the others are single. To help feed the family, her son works as a requirement worker (casual laborer).

This mature rice season, Sao K. lacks a tool for transportation her rice from her field. Therefore, she borrows a loan to buy a cow to harness to her existing cart for delivering her rice.

loans.use: To buy a cow to harness to her cart

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora J. is from the village of Marapong. She is 57 years old. Nora is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Nora owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Nora has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Nora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Nora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Nora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 55 years old. She is married and has nine children, some of whom are still in school. She works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining community. 

Elizabeth has a bread baking business. She bakes bread in a conventional oven in her community and supplies to retailers and beverage sellers. She has been in business for years and desires to expand her business. Elizabeth requests a loan to procure bags of flour, sugar and other ingredients in bulk to be able to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk for baking bread

loans.name: Jekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe Jekafo sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 5 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatorzième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles font comme activités la vente  de fruits, charbons de bois, patates douces,  beurres de Karité etc.   
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1chargement de charrette  en orange, 7 régimes de bananes,  5 paniers d’ananas, 105 sacs de charbons de bois, 2 chargements de charrette en patates et 300kg de beurre de Karité. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  généralement dans les villages  environnants de Kadiolo. Acheminés  à Kadiolo les produits sont stockés dans des magasins à domicile. Elles vendent au marché de Kadiolo, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé comme contribution aux dépenses familiales (nourriture, santé et habillement) et le reste investis dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Jekafo group are essentially married women 37 years old on average, with an average of five children each. Most live in polygamous families in Koko - one of Kadiolo’s neighbourhoods - in the third administrative region of Mali. They cooperate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customer’s needs, and have been granted 14 loans to date. All preceding loans were fully reimbursed. Their activities are selling fruit, charcoal, sweet potatoes, Karité butter, etc. With their new loan, they want to buy: • one cartload of oranges • seven banana bunches • five baskets of pineapples • 105 bags of charcoal • two cartloads of sweet potatoes • 300 kilos of Karité butter They usually get their supplies from villages near Kadiolo. Once brought to Kadiolo, the merchandise is stocked in home-based shops. They sell their wares in the Kadiolo market, as itinerant retailers, or from their home. They are paid directly or quite often on credit, from a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach individual monthly earnings of 37,500 FCFA on average, part of which will be used as a contribution to meeting family expenses (food, healthcare and clothing), and the remainder reinvested in their business activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a business man. He is 40 years old and married with three children. He deals in auto spare parts and is located in Luwero town. He has been in his business for over ten years. Because he doesn't have much capital, he will use the loan to purchase and stock more auto spare parts for sale. He wishes to open up more branches of his business if all goes on well.

loans.use: To purchase and stock more auto spare parts for sale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. is 42 years old and married to Joshua Ochieng. They have six children. They live within Kisumu town. Their first-born son has just graduated from high school, while the youngest has entered kindergarten.

Esther sells maize. Her clients mainly consist of nearby businesspeople, who own maize grinding machines (posho mill), and the local hotels. She hopes to get a lender through Kadet Ltd to enable her to buy five more sacks of maize to add to her stock. 

Her main desire is to expand the business so as to make good profits, which will enable her help her husband to pay school fees for their children.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of maize to add to her stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Repair vehicle used to transport passengers

loans.name: C4564 Twisungane Group

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 34 years old and is married with three children aged between 2 and 6. He also takes care of a dependent. He lives with his family in the city of Kigali, Gasabo district, in the region called Nyarutarama. He is representative of the group called Twisungane in local language.

Jean Bosco has been in his business for three years. He preferred being a businessman to being a farmer because before being in this field he was a farmer and could not earn enough for the basic needs of his family. But now, before the loan, he is able to earn 80,000 RWF per month. Actually, so that he earns these profits is why he starts his business early in the morning, working from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day, even during the weekend.

Jean Bosco is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more various styles of clothes which will help him to attract more customers as well as earn more profit. Once he obtians this loan, he will be able to save money for his future, pay school fees for his children and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Evans Ochieng

texts.en:
Evans Ochieng, 32, is from Migosi in Kisumu city. He is married to Vivian Atieno and they have a son who is six years old and is in primary school.

Evans is a clothes vendor and mainly sells jeans and trousers in an open air area. He is looking for a lender through Kadet Limited to enable him to buy more jeans to add to his inventory. He plans to diversify his inventory by buying other clothes, including children's wear.

His future dream is to have a big stall in the city center and also to open a boutique for his wife. He also wants to ensure that his son gets the best education, and wants to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: Buy clothes to add to his inventory

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Y. is a rice farmer who has been experienced in this business for years. She has already planted her rice but it is not growing well due to the lack of fertilizer. So Y. requests a loan to buy fertilizer for her crop.

Y. is the widowed mother of six children, three of whom are married and others are single.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is 63 years old. She is widowed and has seven children. Some of her children are still in school. She lives with some of her children in a rented apartment in a mining community in Ghana. Apart from mining activity, trading is also a major commercial activity in the town. Hannah a trader. She runs a grocery store by the road side in her community. She sells all kinds of groceries. She has been in business for over 20 years and yearns to procure groceries in bulk so as to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk for resale

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Soutoura sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogames à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatorzième  prêt. Les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles font la vente  d’habits  pour enfants, du beurre de Karité etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3douzaines d’habits  pour enfants et 400kg de noix de Karité pour en faire du beurre de Karité. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Kadiolo ville, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Soutoura group is composed of married women. On average, these women are 35 years of age and have 3 children. They live in monogamous households in the Koko district of city of Kadiolo (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women have decided to work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to satisfy the needs of their clientele. This is their 14th group loan. The previous loans were fully repaid. They sell children's clothing, Shea butter, etc. With this new loan, the plan on buying three dozen sets of children clothing and 400 kg of Shea nuts, which will be used to make Shea butter. They get their supplies at the Kadiolo city market and neighboring villages. They sell their products at the Kadiolo city market, by walking through the neighborhood and around home. The sales are done in cash and often on credit to male and female customers. Each woman expects an average monthly revenue of 20 500 CFA franc; one part will be saved to pay for certain family expenses and the remainder will be put back into the business.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products such as children's clothing and Shea nuts

loans.name: Timothy Odhiambo

texts.en:
Timothy O. is a tailor in the Gudcar area of Kisumu. He is married to Mercy Odhiambo and they have five children. Timothy has been a tailor for the last 16 years and has created a huge clientele because he looks for the latest designs. This makes him beat his competitors.

Timothy is looking for a loan through Kadet Ltd to enable him to buy more sewing machines as well as to employ more people in the business to help with the increasing demand for clothes. He also hopes to use the money to buy material for school uniforms since they are in high demand when schools reopen in the month of January.

His future plans and hopes are to expand his business and become the prime supplier of school uniforms in the entire Kisumu region. His children are in college and high school and he intends to educate them to the university level so that they have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines

loans.name: Salima

texts.en: Salima is a 69-year-old widow with eight children between 26 and 40 years years of age. None of her children goes to school. She owns a three-room house where she is staying with four people. Salima takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying chicken feed at Kalerwe in Kampala district. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week .She receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells at retail to all categories of people. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season (which hinders her customers from reaching her). Salima has been in this business for 10 years and with MCDT for six years. She has had 14 loans, working with the same group mates. Salima joined MCDT because it was near her home and it worked with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken feed and chicks. She hopes to see her business grower bigger and start selling at wholesale only

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is married and the mother of three children who are all currently in school. She is 57 years old and lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She is a food vendor. Hannah prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells the food on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She buys her raw materials from nearby towns. Hannah has been in business for over 30 years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Kankeletigui Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kankeletigui sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne  38 ans et  2 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames  au quartier Babemba,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt. Les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
 Elles font la vente  de  pomme de terre, de Kola , la restauration etc.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 325kg de pomme de terre, 2 paniers de Kola, 200kg de riz, 6 paquets de condiments alimentaires (pour la restauration). 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Médine, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 31.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent avoir plus de fonds pour aménager leur point de vente et ouvrir un magasin afin de mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles.
texts.en:
The Kankeletigui group consists of married women, who on average are 38 years of age and have two children. Most of them live in polygamous households in the Babemba district of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women work in partnership with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to satisfy the needs of their clientele. This is their fourth group loan. The previous loans were fully repaid. The sell potatoes, Kola nuts and have a restaurant business. With this new loan, they plan on buying 325 kg of potatoes, 2 baskets of Kola nuts, 200 kg of rice and 6 packages of food seasoning (for the restaurant). They get their supplies at the Sikasso city market and in the neighbouring villages. They sell their products at the Médine market, by walking through the neighborhood and around home. The sales are done in cash and often on credit to male and female customers. Each woman expects a monthly revenue of 31 500 CFA francs, part of which will be saved to pay for certain family expenses and part of which will be put back into the business. They are striving to decorate their sales booth and open a store to better satisfy their customers.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase diverse products

loans.name: Elsira

texts.en:
Elsira D. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 39 years old. Elsira is single. To make a living, Elsira owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Elsira has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elsira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elsira is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Elsira from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is 47 years old and is married with six children between 5 and 21 years old. She lives in Nyaruguru, in the Southern Province of Rwanda.

Immaculee has been in the business of selling foodstuffs since 2000 and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. every day.

Immaculee is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more foodstuffs such as beans, rice, etc. With these additional foodstuffs for sale, she will be able to satisfy the demands of her customers as well as earn more profits than previously.

Through the earned profits, Immaculee will continue to help her husband in taking care of their children as well as in building a secure future for them.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Berna

texts.en: Berna is a 30-year-old married woman with two children between 13 and 15 years old. All her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she is staying with three people. Berna doesn’t take care of any additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying crates of beer and soda from Kalerwe in Kampala district. She works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week .She receives an average of 12 customers a day and sells at retail to all categories of people.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season (which prevents her customers from reaching). Berna has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for five years. She has had 10 loans, working with the same group mates. Berna joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and soda .She hopes to see her business grower bigger and start selling at wholesale only

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en: W. Gerald is a businessman dealing with the timber business. He is 45 years old and married with two children in school. He has been in his business for over three years. He is using the loan to purchase, transport and sell timber from different locations in Luwero district. He usually supplies timber to different customers in Luwero district. In the future, he plans is to open another timber workshop and extend his services to other areas to make more profit.

loans.use: To purchase timber

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en: Hajara is 52 years old and married with six children between 18 and 31 years old. Two of her children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she is staying with six people. Hajara takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying cattle in the village of Ngoma in Luwero district. She buys cattle and sells them to butchers in Kawempe and Kalerwe areas in Kampala district.  She also sells some cattle to meat packers. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.  She works seven days a week.
