She receives an average of two customers a day and sells to all categories of people at wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality, which makes her business difficult. Hajara has been in this business for four years and with MCDT for eight years. She has had 17 loans, working with the same group mates. Hajara joined MCDT because it was near her home and it worked with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more cattle. She hopes to see her business grower bigger and to open a butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy more cattle for resale

loans.name: Benkelema Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Benkelema sont essentiellement des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 4 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames  au quartier Babemba, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts  précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font le commerce d’articles divers avec  la vente de wax – real, savons, friperie, pâte d’arachide etc.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 14 pièces de pagnes wax – real, 20 cartons de savons, 4 balles de friperies et 350kg d’arachides (pour en faire la pâte d’arachide). 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au  marché de Médine, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Benkelema group are essentially married women with an average age of 35 and 4 children, on average. They mostly live in polygamous families in the Babemba neighborhood of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, and they are on their fourth solidarity loan. The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They sell a variety of items such as Real brand African print cloth, soap, used clothing, peanut butter, etc. With their new loan they intend to buy 14 lengths of Real brand African print cloth, 20 cases of soap, 4 bales of used clothing, and 350 kg of peanuts (to make into peanut butter). They get their inventory at the Sikasso city market and in the surrounding villages. They sell at the Médine market, hawking their wares, and out of their houses, for cash and often on credit, to a clientele composed of men and women. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 30,500 F CFA, of which part will be added to their savings or used for family needs, and the rest invested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for resale

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria J. is from the village of Tumpagon Cagayan de Oro City. She is 53 years old. Maria is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maria is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and the mother of three children who are all currently in school. She is 36 years old and lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. Mary works hard to help her husband to provide for the family. She is a trader. Mary trades in game meat. She buys the meat from local hunters and supplies to food vendors in her community. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy game meat in bulk.

loans.use: To buy game meat in bulk

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: N. Madina is a business lady, 26 years old, and married with three children in school. She has been selling second hand shoes for three years. She is using the loan to purchase different types of shoes, mostly ladies, children, gents, and so forth. Her aim of getting the loan is to expand her business. Her dream is educating her children.

loans.use: To purchase shoes

loans.name: La Paix Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe La paix sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 42ans et  3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames au quartier 1, un des quartiers de la ville de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse de croître. Elles  ont comme activités l’achat vente des fruits, condiments, habits, atiecké etc.
Avec leur prêt, elles comptent acheter, des fruits (1chargement de charrette d’orange + 5 régimes de bananes), 6 paquets de condiments, 3douzaines d’ habits et  5 sacs d’atiecké + 1bidon de 20litre d’huile pour la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville le jour de foire et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent à Loulouni ville  à domicile, au marché et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The members of the group "La Paix" (Peace) are essentially married women with an average age of 42 and three children, on average. They mostly live in monogamous families in District 1, a district of the town of Loulouni, third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their third collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele which grows from day to day. They have businesses buying and selling fruit, condiments, clothing, 'atieké' (cassava grits), etc.

With their loan they are counting on buying fruit (a wagenload of oranges and 5 stalks of bananas) 6 packets of condiments, 3 dozen pieces of clothing, and 5 sacks of 'atieké' + 1 jerrycan of 20 liters of oil for making cooked food.

They buy their inventory at the market of Loulouni town on weekly market days and in surrounding villages. They sell their goods in Loulouli town, out of their houses, in the market, and walking on foot through the neighborhoods. They sell for cash and often for credit to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 32,000 F CFA of which part will be used to add to their savings or for family expenses, and the rest reinvested into their businesses.

They expect to have more working capital so as to better satisfy the needs of their clientele and to be able to set up a sales point.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 50-year-old married mother of seven children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining community. Mary works to support her husband financially to be able to take proper care of the family. Her children are all in school. 

She is a petty trader. She sells on a tabletop in the market square. Mary buys her goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to procure vegetables in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and food items

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 21 years old, is single, and he lives in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately two hours drive from the capital city of Kigali. His village is called Gakenke.

Samuel is a farmer of fruit. He is now requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business and satisfy his customers needs. He has an experience of five years in this field and starts his business activities from 6 a.m. to 3 p.m. every day except on weekends.

After accessing this loan, Samuel will be able to change his business situation, which will allow him to earn more profits. With the extra profits, Samuel expects to get married.
 
By the way, Samuel has the will to succeed in his business, which is proof that he will progress in his activities.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Sérieux Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sérieux sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  4 enfants. Elles  vivent dans des familles monogames au Millionkin, un des quartiers de la ville de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur treizième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse de croître. Tous les prêts précédents se sont bien déroulés. 
Elles  font la vente des fruits et légumes, la préparation et la vente du ‘’dolo’’(la bière locale), la restauration etc.
Avec leur prêt, elles comptent acheter, des fruits et légumes(1chargement de charrette d’orange + 3 régimes de bananes + 1 panier de papayes) , 300kg de maïs + 4 paquets d’ingrédients pour préparer du dolo et 200kg de riz + 5 paquets de condiments pour faire la restauration.
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville le jour de foire et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent à Loulouni ville à domicile, au marché et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sérieux (Serious) are predominantly married women, with an average age of 35 and four children. They live in monogamous families in Millionkin, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Loulouni, third administrative region of Mali. This is their thirteenth partnership with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their clients' needs which never cease to grow. All of the previous loans have gone smoothly. They do sales of fruits and vegetables, the preparation and sale of “dolo” (local beer), catering, etc. With their loan, they plan to buy fruits and vegetables (one wagonload of oranges, three bunches of bananas, one basket of papayas), 300 kg of corn, four packets of ingredients for preparing dolo, 200 kg of rice, and five packets of condiments used in catering. They get their supplies in the Loulouni market on market days and in the surrounding villages. They sell door-to-door in Loulouni, at the market, and as street vendors in neighborhoods. They do cash sales, often offering credit, to male and female customers. They plan to make an average monthly profit of 32,500 FCFA each, part of which will be used for savings and family needs, the other part being invested in the businesses. They plan to have more working capital to better satisfy their customers and be able to set up a shop.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita A. is from the village of Bucana-Sicayab. She is 55 years old. Tita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Tita sells surplus clothing products in the local community. Tita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,900 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Tita joined PMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Tita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Tita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Afua

texts.en:
Afua is married and mothers four children who are all in school. The 44-year-old woman lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. 

Afua works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called banku, from corn dough. It is served hot with soup. 

Afua sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia D. a 36 ans. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs 5 enfants  à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadia D. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est  initiée à l’achat vente des habits  et articles d’occasion autrement dit la friperie. Elle mène son activité à son domicile  où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de trois  ans. Après 2 prêts solidaire (prêt du groupe) avec une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce 4ème prêt,  3 balles de friperie de qualités différentes (T-shirt, Chemises, porte clés, etc.) auprès des grossistes. Elle les revend avec ses enfants de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de sa localité.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia D. is 36 years old. She lives with her husband and their five children in Mamassoni, a town bordering the city of Sikasso in the third administrative region of Mali. Kadia D., after having pursued many professions unsuccessfully, began buying and selling clothing and second-hand clothing. She runs her business from home where she is often solicited by clients for the quality of her products. To satisfy her growing clientele, she decided to rejoin the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso over three years ago. After two group loans with an association of women from her village, she is on her fourth individual loan. All of her previous loans have been repaid in full. With this fourth loan, she plans on buying three loads of second-hand items (t-shirts, blouses, key rings, etc.) from the wholesale distributor. She resells them from a moving cart with her children. Her clients are primarily women in her town. With this loan, she plans on making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her commercial funds, help with her family's expenses, pay the interest on her loan, and invest the rest in her work.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Kanikan's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Kanikan C. is 38 years old and she is the village bank president for a group of 24 people in Prey Prasat Village, Kandal Province. All of the group members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Kanikan C. earns her living as a grocer. Since her business is making less income, she wants to expand it, and so she is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to re-sell. Her husband, Mr. Sandarp P., is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Kanikan C. is the mother of five children. One of them is employed in the garment factory, another is too young to stuD. or work, and the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to re-sell.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence M. is a businesswoman of forty years old. She is married, with two children. She owns a beauty salon and she has been carrying out this business for over eight years. She is using the loan to stock salon items such as hair chemicals, combs, creams, hair relaxers, hairspray, and so forth. Her aim in taking out this loan is to expand her business. Her dream for the future is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To stock salon items such as hair chemicals, combs, creams, hair relaxers, hairspray, and so forth.

loans.name: Cyprienne Eugénie

texts.fr: A. Cyprienne Eugénie est née le 26 Septembre 1965 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Cyprienne Eugénie s'est installée à PK10 Marina, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Mariée à HOUSSOU Emmanuel, un comptable retraité, Cyprienne Eugénie est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Cyprienne Eugénie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Cyprienne Eugénie n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Cyprienne Eugénie vend divers produits (lait, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, produits de toilette, sucre, liqueurs, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Cyprienne Eugénie se ravitaille. Cyprienne Eugénie est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Malgré la passion qu'elle a pour son activité, Cyprienne Eugénie ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour mener à bien son activité et se faire plus de revenus. Pour ce fait, Cyprienne Eugénie sollicite un autre crédit pour renforcer son activité afin de faire face d’une part à ses différentes charges et d'autre part de se faire une épargne consistante.
texts.en:
Cyprienne Eugénie A. was born September 26th, 1965 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Ten years ago, Cyprienne Eugénie moved to PK10 Marina, in the Sèmè-Podji community. Married to Emmanuel Houssoi, a retired accountant, Cyprienne Eugénie is the mother of four children who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband. Together, the couple provides for the family. Cyprienne Eugénie did not go to school. To make ends meet, she sells different products (milk, preserves, pastas, toiletries, sugar, liquor, etc.) from her home. Cyprienne Eugénie buys her supplies In Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Cyprienne Eugénie is a good client of ALIDé who has repaid all of her loans. Despite the passion she has for her work, she does not have enough funds to run her business well and increase her revenue. To do so, Cyprienne Eugénie is asking for another loan to strengthen her business. Part of the loan will be used to meet her financial needs and another part to make a consistent savings account.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items (preserves, milk, pasta, sugar)

loans.name: Djénèba

texts.fr:
Djénèba B. a 42 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses cinq enfants plus 8 enfants adoptifs, à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école, elle s’est très vite initiée à l’activité d’achat et  de vente des  tubercules (Pomme de terre, patate, igname), de légumes, etc il y a maintenant vingt ans. Elle mène son activité au nouveau marché de Médine Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de quatre ans. 
Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 40 caisses de pomme de terre, en gros sur place auprès des producteurs venant à la foire. Elle effectue sa  vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle riche et variée.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèba B. is 42 years old and lives with her large family - her husband, five children and eight adopted children. They live in Hamdallaye, one of the popular quarters of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Never having had the chance to go to school, she entered the business of buying and selling tubers (potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams), vegetables, and other items twenty years ago. She does her business at the new market of Médine Sikasso. Wanting to better satisfy her growing number of clients, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso over four years ago. After two group loans with an association of women from her village, she is on her second individual loan. All of her previous loans have been repaid in full. With this loan, she plans on buying 40 cases of potatoes from the wholesale distributors who sell at the fair. She does her sales at retail, in cash and credit, to a rich and varied clientele. Djénèbe plans on making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which she will use to increase her commercial funds, contribute to her family's expenses, pay the interest on her loan, and invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Potatoes

loans.name: Vicentia

texts.en: Vicentia is married and the mother of four children, who are all in school. This twenty-seven-year-old woman lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. Vicentia works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She is a tie-dye and batik production businesswoman. She makes the designs and supplies them to retailers, as well as taking orders. Vicentia also sells at a table in the local market square. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy bales of mercerized cotton, dyes, wax, and other working materials.

loans.use: To buy cotton, dyes, wax and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Josephine is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Yiriba

texts.fr:
Âgé de 42 ans, Monsieur  Yiriba D.est un polygame qui a 3 femmes, 12 enfants et réside à Lafiabougou, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur D.après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au commerce notamment à l’achat vente du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois depuis plus de dix ans. Il dispose de son propre véhicule avec lequel il transporte ses bois et charbons dans les brousses. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, 5 chargements de bois de chauffe et 10 sacs de charbon de bois. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yiriba D.is a 42-year-old polygamist who has three wives and 12 children. He lives in Lafiabougou, one of the outlying quarters of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). Mr. Diamoutènè, after having tried many activities unsuccessfully, entered commerce over ten years ago, primarily buying and selling firewood and wood coal. He has his own vehicle with which he transports his wood and coal to the back country. He is often solicited by his clients for the quality of his products. To satisfy his growing number of clients, Yiriba decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with which he is on his first individual loan. With this first loan, he plans on buying five loads of firewood and ten bags of wood coal. He foresees making a monthly profit of 250,000 FCFA which he will use to increase his commercial funds, contribute to his family's expenses, pay the interest on his loan, and invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of loads of firewood and bags of wood coal

loans.name: Angmor

texts.en: Angmor is married and is the mother of five children, who are all in school. The forty-year-old woman lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Angmor is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called "banku", made from corn dough. It is served hot with soup. Angmor sells her products on a table by the road side in her community. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 26 years old, and he is still single. He lives in Nyaruguru, in the Southern Province of Rwanda.

Emmanuel started his business of selling secondhand clothes in 2008. He operates his business from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. every day.

Emmanuel is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing more clothes (clothes for babies and women) because he used to sell only men’s clothes. Because those clothes seem to be so much demanded by a number of his customers, he hopes to earn more profits.

With these profits, Emmanuel will build his secure future as he is also in the process of getting married.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes for babies and women

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria S. is from the village of Owaon. She is 48 years old. Victoria is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Victoria owns and operates a business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,700 PHP, on average, a month for these activities.

In 2007, Victoria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Victoria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz O. is from the village of El Salvador, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old, and single. To make a living, Luz owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Luz is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Luz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 18 Novembre 1979 à Sikasso, Monsieur Ousmane Samaké  est marié  et réside avec son épouse à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso  (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur S.après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce notamment à l’achat vente des matériels d’électricité il y a maintenant sept ans. Il dispose actuellement d’une quincaillerie il y a environ deux ans, auparavant il menait l’activité de façon ambulante avec une clientèle composée généralement d’entrepreneurs et surtout d’électriciens. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt  et le premier a été correctement remboursé. 
 Il compte acheter  avec ce  deuxième prêt, 25 cartons de contacteurs, 30 cartons d’ampoules de différentes sortes, 35 paires de réglettes, 15 paquets de disjoncteurs, des câbles etc. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako, Bobo Dioulasso, Koumassi et Abidjan (respectivement au Mali, en Burkina Faso, au Ghana et en Côte d’Ivoire) avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit.
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on 18th November 1979 in Sikasso, Mr. Ousmane S.is married and lives with his wife in Mamassoni, one of the outer neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having run several unsuccessful businesses, Mr. S.began trading, principally in the purchase and sale of electrical materials, seven years ago. He has had a hardware store for two years now; before that he ran his business on a door-to-door basis with a customer base composed generally of entrepreneurs, and above all electricians. He is in much demand from his customers because of the quality of his products. In order to satisfy the ever increasing number of customers, he decided to join the micro-finance company, Soro Yiriwaso, and he is now on his second loan, the first having been repaid without incident. With this second loan he is planning to buy 25 boxes of contactors (or circuit protection devices), 30 boxes of different types of bulbs, 35 pairs of rails, 15 packets of circuit breakers, cables etc. He stocks up in Bamako, Bobo Dioulasso, Koumassi and Abidjan (respectively in Mali, Burkina Faso, Ghana and the Ivory Coast) before retailing them for cash or credit. He intends with this loan to make a monthly profit of 250,000 FCFA, which will be used principally to increase his working capital, to contribute to family expenses and to pay the interest on his loan; he will invest the remainder in his business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hardware materials

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 32 years old. She is single and has no children. Diana lives in a rented apartment in a mining and commercial community in Ghana. As many women in the community do, Diana trades to provide for herself. She trades in all kinds of textile materials. Diana buys the materials from nearby towns and then sells them door-to-door and travels to nearby communities to sell there on their market days. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure textiles in bulk.

loans.use: To buy textiles.

loans.name: Meldred

texts.en:
Meldred H. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Meldred is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Meldred owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Meldred has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Meldred joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meldred has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Meldred is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Meldred from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is married and has given birth to one child who is currently in school. The 36-year-old woman lives with her husband and child in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Juliet is a trader. She prepares all kinds of cereals and supplies them to retailers and food vendors in her community. Juliet buys her goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 4 enfants et vivant dans des familles  nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans la ville de Yanfolila qui relève de la 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière et de faire assez de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce des condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe et tous les huit  prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 50 boîtes de 2kg de  concentrée de tomate, 20 sacs de 25kg de sel de cuisine, 30 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi et diverses autres qualités de condiments. 
Les produits sont achetés auprès des grossistes de Yanfolila pour les revendre ensuite dans le grand marché de la même ville. Leur clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes et les condiments sont vendus en détail au comptant ou à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA par mois qui sera réutilisé dans leur activité.
texts.en:
The Badenya group is made up of married women who have an average age of 32 years, with an average of four children, and live in nuclear families with just their children and husbands. These women live in the town of Yanfolila which is in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They got to know each other via business connections. With the intention of increasing their financial resources and in order to build up enough stock to satisfy their customers' needs, they decided to join the micro-finance company, Soro Yiriwaso, and run a business selling food condiments. They are on their ninth group loan and the previous eight loans have all been repaid without incident. With this new loan they are planning to buy 50 2kg boxes of tomato purée, 20 25kg bags of kitchen salt, 30 packets of 100 "Maggi" stock cubes and various other types of condiment. These products are purchased from wholesalers in Yanfolila to be sold on afterwards in the large market in the same town. Their customer base is made up primarily of women, and the condiments are sold retail for cash or credit. With this loan the women hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA per month which will be reinvested into their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food condiments

loans.name: Matea

texts.en:
Matea P. is from the village of Westfield Iponan, in Cagayan de Oro City. She is a 58-year-old widow with three school-age children. To earn a living, Matea owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. More specifically, her income is primarily derived from hairdressing and beauty services she provides to local community members. Matea has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month on account of these activities.

In 2009, Matea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she was better equipped to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Notably, Matea has already successfully repaid a prior loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to expand the services she could provide to her customers. Matea is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 8,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to further expand the business. This loan would be the second loan taken out by Matea from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and seeks to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her service business

location.town: Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 55-year-old married woman with seven children, some of whom are still in school. She works hard to support her husband as they strive to provide for their family. Gladys lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining community.

To earn a living, Gladys is engaged in the business of baking bread. Indeed, she bakes bread in a conventional oven in her community and she supplies the bread to retailers and beverage sellers. Gladys has been in business for four years and is now seeking to expand her business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $725 to procure bags of flour, sugar and other ingredients in bulk to be able to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional raw ingredients (e.g., flour and sugar)

loans.name: Nidjat

texts.en: Nidjat S. is a young, single man living in Baku city, Azerbaijan. He explains that he was born in 1987. For three years now, Nidjat has been in the business of selling clothing. He is now seeking a loan in the amount of 2,000 AZN ($2,500) to improve his business by expanding the clothing display area.

loans.use: To improve his business by expanding the display area

loans.name: Bary Maramou I Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bary Maramou 1 est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans la ville de Yanfolila qui relève de la 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des relations professionnelles. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière et de faire assez de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le précèdent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, auprès des fournisseurs de Yanfolila, 3 tonnes de maïs, 4tonnes de sorgho et 2 tonnes de petit mil. 
Les produits seront revendus dans le marché de Yanfolila, en gros et en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle  composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 40.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé dans l’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Bary Maramou 1 is composed of married women who average 28 years of age and three children each.  The women live in nuclear  families with their children and husband, and they reside in the city of Yanfolila, which is part of the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.  They know one another through professional ties.   With the intention of increasing their financial resources and having enough inventory to satisfy customer needs, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to do commerce in grains.  They are now on their second solidarity loan.  The previous one was properly repaid. With this new loan, they intend to go to Yanfolila suppliers to buy:  three tonnes of corn, four tonnes of sorghum, and two tonnes of petit mil (millet). The goods will be sold retail and wholesale at the Yanfolila market accepting cash or credit from customers composed of men and women.  With this loan, the group members hope to obtain a profit of 40,000 francs CFA per month that will be used for educating their children. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buyiing grain

loans.name: Lisalie

texts.en: Lisalie C. is from the village of Westfield, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Lisalie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lisalie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lisalie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan L. is 46 years old and lives in Angk village, Kandal province. To earn a living, she and her husband (pictured on the left) are farmers. More specifically, they own 1.3 hectares, on which they cultivate rice. They have five children, two of whom are laborers in the local village, while the others are students at the local school. To improve and expand their farming operations, Mrs. Chan L. is seeking a loan in the amount of $500 to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and rice seeds.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional fertilizers, gasoline, and rice seeds

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is a 35-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are still in school. She works hard to support her husband and to provide for their family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining community.

To earn a living, she is engaged in the business of baking bread. Specifically, Theresa bakes bread in a conventional oven in her community and supplies her breads to retailers and beverage sellers. She has been in this line of business for seven years but now hopes to expand the business. Therefore, Theresa is requesting a loan in the amount of $850 to procure bags of flour, sugar, and other ingredients in bulk to be able to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional raw ingredients (e.g., flour and sugar)

loans.name: Bary Maramou Ii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bary Maramou 2 est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogames avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans la ville de Yanfolila qui relève de la 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière et de faire assez de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le précèdent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 5 tonnes de maïs et 2  tonnes de petit mil avec les fournisseurs des villages environnants de Yanfolila pour ensuite les revendre sur le marché de Yanfolila, en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes comptent obtenir un bénéfice de 40 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé dans l’habillement et l’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The group Bary Maramou 2 is composed of married women who average 26 years of age and four children each.  The women live in monogamous families with their children and husband, and they reside in the city of Yanfolila, which is part of the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.  They know one another through business ties.  With the intention of increasing their financial resources and having enough inventory to satisfy customer needs, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to do commerce in grains.  They are now on their second solidarity loan.  The preceding one was properly repaid. With this new loan, they intend to buy:  five tonnes of corn and two tonnes of petit mil (millet) from suppliers of villages surrounding Yanfolila.  The goods are then to be resold retail at the Yanfolila market in cash transactions.  Their customers are composed of men and women.  With this loan, the group members plan on obtaining a profit of 40,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to provide clothing and schooling for their children. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Adèle

texts.fr: T. Adèle est née le 31 décembre 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Adèle vit depuis 7ans à Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-podji. Mariée à HOUNZANDJI Bienvenu,un couturier, Adèle est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Adèle exerce comme activité principale le vente de péllicules, cassettes, albums, piles et cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Adèle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et vend ses produits à Akpokpota dans les environs de son domicile. Adèle n'a jamais fréquenté l'école mais possède à son actif 8 annnées d'expérience dans l'exercice de son activité. Adèle est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursé. Dans le souci de renforcer et de diversifier ses activités, Adèle désire obtenir un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
T. Adèle was born on December 31, 1981 in  Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She has been living for seven years in Sèkandji, in the community of Sèmè-podji.  Married to HOUNZANDJI Bienvenu, a clothier, she is the mother of two children who are all in school.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  Adèle runs a business selling camera film, cassettes, albums, batteries, and phone recharge cards.  She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and sells her goods in Akpokpota in the area around her home.  Adèle never attended school but has eight years of experience as her asset derived from operating her business.  She is a previous ALIDé client who has already benefited from two loans, both of which she repaid.  Wanting to strengthen and diversify her business, Adèle would like to obtain a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying film, casettes, albums, phone cards

loans.name: Souleymane Manankoro

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane Manankoro D. est un homme marié de 36 ans qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son père dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougouni dans le quartier Médine  (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant vite abandonné l’école dès son jeune âge, il décida d’apprendre le métier de tailleur auprès de son oncle.
Avec une quinzaine d’année d’expérience dans le domaine, il maîtrise bien son travail et est très sollicité pour la qualité de ses prestations.
Pour renforcer son activité, il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il  est à sa première expérience. 
Avec ce  premier prêt il compte acheter, des tissus pour les coudre et les vendre à des particuliers et aux commerçants.
Il s’approvisionne en tissus à Bamako (Capitale de République du Mali). Les fêtes religieuses constituent les périodes de ses fortes ventes. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 60.500 FCFA qu’il utilisera pour améliorer son atelier afin d’attirer plus de clients, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille et ouvrir un autre atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane Manankoro D. is a 36-year-old married man who lives with his wife and children at his father's place and in a large traditional extended family in the Médine district (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Having quickly dropped out of school at a young age, he decided to learn the trade of tailoring from his uncle.  With fifteen years of experience in this domain, he has a good command of his work and is in high demand for the quality of his services.  To bolster his business, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, and this is his first experience now.  With this initial loan, he intends to buy some cloth to sew and to sell to individuals and merchants.  He supplies himself with cloth in Bamako (capital of Mali).  The religious holidays constitute the times when his sales are strong.  Souleymane plans on earning a monthly profit of 60,500 francs CFA that he will use to improve his workshop, so as to attract more customers, to help with family expenses, and to open another workshop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna F. is from the village of Owaon in Dapitan City. She is 46 years old, married, and has three school-age children. To earn a living, Myrna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, she operates a general store, selling a variety of products to local community members. Myrna has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP per month on account of these activities.

In 2007, Myrna joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) to gain access to financial services. As a result, she was better equipped to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Notably, Myrna recently repaid a loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This prior loan was used to to purchase additional inventory for the store, as well as fertilizers for gardening activities. Myrna is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 14,900 PHP ($325), which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to supplement her existing working capital. This loan would be the fourth loan taken out by Myrna from PMPC and her second loan via Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor by using the Grameen micro-lending model.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Madame Bintou Toé  est âgée de 56 ans, mariée  et mère  de 4  enfants.  Elle  vit avec son mari et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Sokala de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 10ème  année (du système éducatif Malien) elle mena plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus telles la vente de jus de fruits, d’eau glacée etc. Finalement elle se lança dans la confection de sacs en nylon et des chaises en nylon après une année d’apprentissage qui  l’amena dans deux pays le Bénin et la Côte d’ivoire. Après cette phase d’apprentissage riche d’enseignements qui a fait d’elle aujourd’hui une femme aux mains de génie, elle jouit d’une grande réputation nationale et internationale. Elle reçoit des commandes de l’extérieur et ses clients sont principalement des touristes  étrangers qui adorent son œuvre.
Pour faire un sac, elle a besoin de 4 rouleaux de fil en nylon multicolore plus du bois rouge (bété). Ensuite elle tricote à l’aide d’un crochet métallique. La fabrication d’un sac peut prendre 2 jours.
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de participer aux festivals sur le Niger du mois prochain, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elle est à son 1er prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 10 paquets de fil en nylon, 10 barres de fer pour chaises. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Madame   Bintou Toé  vend au comptant  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes (étrangers et nationaux).
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui servira de fonds de roulement et d’appui dans la prise en charges des dépenses du foyer. 
Son ambition est d’agrandir son atelier.
texts.en:
Ms. Bintou Toé is 56 years old, married, and the mother of four.  She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional family in the Sokala district of Ségou (4th  administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Having dropped out of school in the 10th year (of the education system of Mali), she worked at several revenue-generating businesses, such as selling fruit juices, ice water, etc.  In the end, she embarked on making nylon bags and nylon chairs after a one-year apprenticeship, which had lead her to two countries, Benin and Cote d'Ivoire.  After this apprenticing phase, rich with learning, which has produced in her a genius at handicraft, she enjoys a great reputation nationally and internationally.  She receives orders from abroad. And her customers are mainly foreign tourists, who love her work.  To make a bag, Bintou needs four rolls of multi-colored nylon string, plus some red wood (bété).  Then, she knits them using a metallic hook.  Making a bag can take two days.  Planning to increase her business capital, in order to take part in the festivals on the Niger next month, she turned toward micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first individual loan.  She intends to use this loan to buy ten packets of nylon string and ten iron bars for chairs.  She supplies herself locally.  She makes her sales in cash to customers composed of women and men (foreigners and nationals).  With this loan, Bintou envisions realizing a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA.  This profit will be used as operating funds and as support in covering household expenses.  Her ambition is to expand her workshop. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying string and iron bars

loans.name: Fanta

texts.fr:
Madame  Fanta Kébé est âgée de 31 ans, mariée  et mère  de 2 enfants.  Elle  vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Médine de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Pour des raisons sociales elle abandonna très tôt l’école pour faire le commerce de poissons auprès de sa mère. Son apprentissage dura juste quelques  6 mois. Aujourd’hui elle évolue de ses propres ailes et jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété, sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses articles.   
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48 mois, après 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels correctement  remboursés. Elle est à son 3ème  prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 200kgs de poissons capitaine. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Madame Fanta Kébé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de renforcer son fonds de commerce et  d’aider son père dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.  
Son ambition est de construire une maison.
texts.en:
Ms. Fanta Kébé is 31 years old, married, and the mother of two children.  She lives in a large traditional family in the Médine district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  For societal reasons, she dropped out of school early, so as to sell fish along side her mother.  Her apprenticeship lasted only six months or so.  Today, she is more than a fledgling, advancing on her own and enjoying recognition and a large customer base.  Her selling power is due to the quality of her goods.  With plans to increase her business capital, in order to realize more profits, she turned to micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  She has been associated with it for the last 48 months and has properly repaid four solidarity loans and two individual loans.  She is now on her third individual loan.  Fanta intends to use this loan to buy 200 kg of capitaine fish.  She supplies herself locally.  She accepts cash or credit from customers composed of women and men.  With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA.  This profit will enable Fanta to bolster her capital and to help her father with covering family expenses.  Her ambition is to build a house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish

loans.name: God's Goodness Group

texts.en:
Kebbeh B. K. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called God’s Goodness. She is 40 years old and is busy with 3 children aged 15-22 years old. Their educational level is 4th-6th grade. She also cares for 2 nieces. Kebbeh and her family live in the Red-light Sore Clinic community. She had to leave school after 8th grade due to poverty.

Kebbeh’s business is the sale of rice. She buys rice in large bags and sells it at retail prices by the cup in the Red-light market, which is the biggest market in Paynesville, Liberia. She has been running this business for 18 years and hopes to start importing rice to Liberia in the near future. Kebbeh started her rice-selling business with 500 Liberian Dollars given to her by her mother. She is very friendly and talks to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Kebbeh needs this loan to add to her capital and improve her business. She dreams of helping her children as much as she can, in order for them to have a good future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kebbeh is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Sabenti Group

texts.en:
Above in the photo are members of the Sabenti group. They are petty businesspeople in the northern city of Makeni in Sierra Leone. They have applied for a group loan of 3,000,000 from SMT/Kiva in order to expand their businesses, both in size and in quality. In this way, they can make more sales; earn more profit, and consequently improve their standard of living.

The leader of the group is 37-year-old Abdul K., in the left in the photo. Abdul was born in Makump village about 5 miles from Makeni. He is married to a businesswoman and they have 5 children – 2 in primary school and 3 in secondary school.

Abdul sells rice, salt, and palm oil. He has been a businessman for many years now. With his share of the loan, he will expand his business by buying wholesale the above-mentioned items.

loans.use: Buy rice, salt, and palm oil

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Horonya est composé de neuf femmes dont huit mariées dans des grandes  familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans, 4 enfants et habitent le chef lieu de  commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du Mali.) 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités commerciales. 
Elles font le commerce d’articles divers, la transformation de grains de Néré en Sounbala, la restauration etc. 
Dans le souci  d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 1er  prêt de groupe.
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter,  5 sacs de riz,  2sacs de farine de blé, 2 bidons d’huile de 20 litres, 2 caisses de pommes de terre, 2cartons de spaghettis, 3 cartons de bananes plantains, et des condiments (nécessaires à la préparation des différents mets alimentaires), 2 sacs de graines de Néré,  2 colis de calebasses, 1colis d’ustensiles  en plastiques, 48 paires de chaussures et 2 cartons de parfums. 
La plus parts de  leurs marchandises seront achetées sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare. La pomme de terre, les bananes plantain sont fournies par les forains venant de Loulouni. Les graines de Néré sont transformées en Sounbala. 
La vente se fait au marché de Cinzana Gare, dans les gargotes et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 14.100FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt, à l’achat de nourriture, des fournitures scolaires  et à la participation aux évènements sociaux. 
Leur ambition est la diversification de leurs activités avec  l’élevage de petits  ruminants.
texts.en:
The group Horonya is composed of nine women, of whom eight are married, in large traditional extended families.  The women average 39 years of age and four children each living in the capital of the rural community Cinzana Gare (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of community, kinship, and their commercial work.  They work at selling a variety of goods, food catering, and processing néré seeds to make sounbala (a pounded and fermented condiment formed into balls and used in cooking). Concerned about increasing their business volume, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their first group loan.  This loan will be used to buy:  five sacks of rice, two sacks of wheat flour, two 20-liter containers of oil, two cases of potatoes, two boxes of spaghetti, three boxes of plantains, and some condiments (necessary for making different dishes), two sacks of néré seeds, two packages of calabashes, a package of plastic utensils, 48 pairs of shoes, and two boxes of perfumes.  Most of their merchandise will be purchased locally at the Cinzana Gare weekly fair.  The potatoes and plantains are furnished by fair vendors coming from Loulouni.  The néré seeds are processed into sounbala.  Sales are made at the Cinzana Gare market in stalls and in homes.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women. The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 14,100 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to buy food and school supplies, and to take part in societal events.  Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by raising small ruminants. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a variety of goods

loans.name: Assa

texts.en: Assa is a 38-year-old married mother of three children aged 15 to 20 years.  All her children go to school and take care of additional family members. She owns a four-room house where she lives with four people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  Assa sells handicrafts in the Nakulabye market. To get handicrafts to sell, she travels to and from shops at the National Theatre, which is one of the busiest wholesale markets for handicrafts in Uganda. She works six days a week in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.  She serves an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail and wholesale prices.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children, and monthly market dues for her business. Her major business challenge is transportation of bales of products like mats, tablecloths, and hats.   Assa has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for twelve years. She is currently on her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates. Assa joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more handicrafts.  She aspires to grow her business and start selling at wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more handicrafts for resale.

loans.name: Gadir

texts.en: Gadir S. was born in 1977. This young man is married and has a child. S.'s family lives in the Fuluri region. He has been in his business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy fruit and vegetables to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba is married and has a daughter. This is an average family from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. However, Mahbuba is a unique entrepreneur. She has been selling fabric for national dresses in the central city market for about 11 years, running her own small venture successfully. The secret of her success is simple: not only does she tell her customers the benefits of her products, but she also gives them a sense of relationship which brings them back again and again. However, she doesn’t want to stop where she is with her venture. Mahbuba is seeking a loan of $1000 USD to re-stock the merchandise in her store. We believe that Mahbuba’s desire to excel in pleasing her customers will ensure her further success and encourage new customers to buy from her. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fabric to sell for sewing national dresses.

loans.name: Dilshodboy

texts.en:
Dilshodboy is 26 years old and lives with his wife and three children. He is a humble farmer dedicated to growing vegetables and raising his two sheep on his land. To do this work, he has to leave early in the morning and go back home late. But when he sees the results, it comforts him. He wants to increase his production because he knows that he will have better results from a larger harvest.  The vegetables will also need to be of better quality in order to get more income from the sales. In order to do all this, he needs to invest large amounts of money.  He wants to increase his vegetable production and purchase more sheep to breed. That is why he applied to IMON International for a loan of 10500 Somoni.
