loans.use: Purchasing of fertilizer and sheep

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Sabougnouman est composé de dix femmes dont deux veuves et huit  mariées dans des  grandes  familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 41 ans, 4 enfants et habitent le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du  Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités commerciales, essentiellement axées sur le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. 
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter,  6 pièces de bazin,  10 pièces de pagnes wax, 4 draps, 2 paires de rideaux, 6 pagnes tissés, 4 couvertures tissées ; 2 sacs de riz, 1sac de patates, 2 bidons d’huile de 20 litres, 150kg de beurre de karité, 1sac d’oignon frais, 1panier de choux pommés, 1 panier de tomates fraîches, 1panier de gombo séché, 3 cartons de thé, 1sac de sucre, 6 cartons de savon, 2 sacs de savon local « kabacourouni » et 5 moutons sur pied. 
Toutes leurs marchandises seront achetées sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare, de Ségou et de Tona.  
Le riz est préparé en plats alimentaires avant sa vente. En plus elles font des fritures de patates, de poissons frais, de la farine de blé. 
La vente se fait au marché de Cinzana Gare  et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 14.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt, à l’achat de nourriture, des fournitures scolaires et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions et funérailles). 
Leur principale ambition est  l’élevage de petits.
texts.en:
The group Sabougnouman is composed of ten women, of whom two are widows and eight are married, in large traditional families.  The women average 41 years of age and four children each living in the capital of the rural community of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of community, kinship, and their commercial work, which essentially revolves around commerce in various goods and in food catering. In order to satisfy the needs of their customers, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their first group loan.  This loan will be used to buy:  six bolts of damask fabrics, ten bolts of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), four bed sheets, two pairs of curtains, six woven pagnes, four woven blankets; two sacks of rice, a sack of potatoes, two 20-liter containers of oil, 150 kg of shea butter, a sack of fresh onions, a basket of cabbage, a basket of fresh tomatoes, a basket of dried okra, three boxes of tea, a sack of sugar, six boxes of soap, two sacks of the local soap kabacourouni, and five heads of sheep.  All their merchandise will be purchased locally at the weekly fairs of Cinzana Gare, Ségou, and Tona.  The rice is cooked for meals and then sold.  In addition, they make fritters out of potatoes, fresh fish, and flour.  They make their sales at the Cinzana Gare market and in homes.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women.  The group members hope to earn an average monthly profit of 14,500 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to buy food and school supplies, and to take part in societal events (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals).  Their main ambition is to raise small ruminants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Timap Bifo Group

texts.en:
These entrepreneurs have formed themselves into a group of 5, made Kadiatu S. (in the middle of the photo) their leader, and named their group 'Timap Bifo'. Now, they have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can expand their businesses both in size and quality. Consequently, sales and profit-to-sales margin will also improve. In this way, their living standards will improve.

Their leader, Kadiatu, is now 29 years old. She was born in Kono, eastern Sierra Leone. She is married to a professional worker and they have 2 children, both of whom are in primary school. Kadiatu has been selling perfume and charcoal for 5 years now. With her share of the loan, she will buy more perfume and charcoal to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy more perfume and charcoal to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Uljaboy

texts.en:
Uljaboy happily works on his farm growing vegetables which helps him pay the household expenses and the necessities of his five children. His children are studying at school and need various supplies to keep studying. He wishes as a father that he can give his children what they need so they can progress through school and later work at jobs other than those in the agricultural sector. In this way he thinks that many people consider him a hard-working and selfless father.

Nonetheless, he now needs help in order to continue working. He needs to buy organic and chemical fertilizers, which are very important for growing products according to market demands. With your help, Uljaboy will be able to support his children's success.

loans.use: To purchase organic and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Saifullo

texts.en: Born in 1980, N. Saifullo is married and has one child. He is a farmer and agriculture has become his beloved job, and has been the principle source of income for him for the last ten years. On his land he produces different kinds of produce. Thanks to his experiences that he gained during ten years, he gets a rich harvest every year from his land. In light of the current high demand, Saifullo would like to improve his land and production to meet the market. In order to do this, he is seeking a loan of 8,000 Somoni to buy fuels and lubricants and fertilizer for improving and expanding his harvest. He would then be able to better take care of his family's health and food needs. You could become an important part of the life of Saifullo’s family. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him. loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Yèrèdon Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Yèrèdon est composé de six femmes toutes mariées, dans des grandes  familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et  habitent le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté.
 Dans le souci d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités commerciales, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme  crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt de groupe après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
 Ce  prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 2sacs de riz, 1 sac de patate, 4 bidons d’huile de 20 litres, 40kg de poissons fumés et séchés, 2 sacs de graines d’arachide, des condiments : 1panier d’oignon frais, 10kg gros oignon,   1 panier d’oignon séché, 5kg de Sounbala,  2 paquets de cubes maggi,  2 kg de poivre, 1panier de chou pommé 1 de panier de tomates fraîches et 20 paquets de mèche. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare et  à Ségou. Le riz est réservé pour la restauration. Une partie des patates est frite pour être vendue. La vente se fait au marché de Cinzana Gare, à domicile et en ambulants les jours ordinaires. Les ventes se font au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et d’enfants pour la patate frite. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.415FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement du prêt,  à l’achat de fournitures scolaires, de médicaments et à la participation aux évènements sociaux.
texts.en:
The group Yèrèdon is composed of six women, all married, in large traditional families.  The women average 35 years of age and four children each living in the capital of the rural community of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of community and kinship.  Concerned about increasing the volume of their businesses, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their second group loan after having properly repaid the first one.  The new loan will be used to buy:  two sacks of rice, a sack of potatoes, four 20-liter drums of oil, 40 kg of smoked and dried fish, two sacks of peanuts, some condiments (including a basket of fresh onions, 10 kg of big onions, a basket of dried onions, 5 kg of sounbala, two packets of Maggi bouillon cubes, 2 kg of black pepper, a basket of cabbages, and a basket of fresh tomatoes), and twenty packets of hair extensions. The group members stock up locally at the weekly fairs of Cinzana Gare and Ségou.  The rice is reserved for food catering.  A portion of the potatoes is fried to be sold.  Sales are made at the Cinzana Gare market, in homes, and door-to-door on ordinary days.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men, and women, and children for the fried potatoes. The group members plan on earning an average monthly profit of 20,415 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to buy school supplies and medicines, and to take part in societal events.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Dilfuza

texts.en: O. Dilfuza is 32 years old. She is married and is the mother of four children. Dilfuza's lack of a stable job and the slow productivity of her husband's business as an entrepreneur didn't leave enough money to pay the expenses of the family. This was the reason that Dilfuza decided to start her own business nine years ago, selling the fabrics of the national dresses. Little by little Dilfuza has made her business grow and by allowing her clients to pay in installments her orders are getting bigger. Now her business is running normally. However, she would like to continue bettering herself and her business so her situation will be stable in the future. Dilfuza is asking for a loan of $2,000. With this money, she will be able to buy seasonal fabrics for the national dresses. The power to help her business grow is in your hands. loans.use: To purchase seasonal fabrics for increasing her range of goods

loans.name: Union Group

texts.en: Annie G. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called Union Group. She is 38 years old and is married with two children aged 7 and 9, with educational levels of kindergarten and 1st grade. Annie and her family live in the Bernard farm community on Kakata highway, but she sells in the Red-light market which is the biggest market in Paynesville, Liberia. Annie is illiterate due to poverty. Annie’s business is dressmaking materials. She buys them from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in the Red-light market. She has been running this business for more than twenty years and hopes to own a shop. Annie started by selling coconuts and her capital was 5,000 Liberian Dollars, given to her by her husband. She is popular in the Red-light market and talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Annie needs this loan to purchase more underwear and bras for resale. She dreams of establishing the business for her children so that they can fend for themselves in the future. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Annie is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more underwear and bras to sell

loans.name: Muharram

texts.en: Muharram is a lovely 27-year-old woman who lives with her three children. She runs a small fabrics-selling business where she offers at the market a variety of types of fabrics for different tastes and ages. Muharram is asking for this loan so that she can buy a larger quantity of goods. The extra capital will enable her to expand her merchandise and thus improve her business and increase her profits. Muharram’s dreams are to have her own large store one day but most importantly, to enable her children to have a better future, once they start to study at school, then university, become professionals, and lead healthy and comfortable lives. On behalf of Muharram and everyone here at IMON International, thank you for your support! loans.use: To purchase new fabrics in order to increase the range of her goods

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en:
Dilbar R., 52, is a very diligent woman. She is married to a farmer and they have four children. Thanks to her dear husband's seeding skills she is very familiar with agricultural work. Her loving husband gave her farming fields 10 years ago and she's been working them ever since. At the same time she raises and sells cattle. These activities have helped to pay the economic expenses of her family. Dilbar's wishes to improve the quality of her products are what drives her to request a 5000 Somoni loan. She would like to acquire mineral fertilizers in order to obtain excellent products for this harvesting season. Make her request possible so that this hardworking mother can continue to develop her work, which gives her a lot of satisfaction.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great philosophers, scientists, and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina, Firdousi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others.The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Tp purchase mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Nori

texts.en:
Nori S. is 45 years old. She is married and a mother of two children who are in school. Nori started her business because she needed extra income to be able to pay for household and personal expenses. She also needed her own income in order to afford her home. Nori began selling teenagers clothing and shoes 10 years ago. She had always liked sales and the business did well after it started. Since then, she has continued to sell clothing. To expand her business Nori is requesting a loan of $1500 USD. She would like to earn more and to meet all of her children’s expenses.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Description,	Composé d’une célibataire, deux veuves et cinq mariées, les membres groupe Badegna vivent majoritairement dans des  familles monogames, avec  en moyenne 39 ans, 4 enfants et habitant le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali). 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers, la restauration et la production de produits alimentaires.
Après avoir bien remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur  2ème prêt solidaire.  
Ce nouveau prêt servira à acheter,  4sacs de riz, 7 sacs de mil, 3sacs d’oignon frais, 5 cartons de savon de lessive, 1 sac de savon local « kabacourouni » 6 sacs de charbon de bois, 2 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe, 3 pièces de pagnes wax, 4 pièces de pagnes fancy, 4 douzaines de paires de chaussures,  4sacs de farine de blé, 2 bidons d’huile alimentaires de 20 litres et 48 bouteilles vides. 
Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (habits et chaussures), à Ségou (riz,  farine de blé,  oignons frais, l’huile et bouteilles vides), et à Cinzana Gare pour les autres marchandises. La vente des articles se fait au marché de Cinzana et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 19.125FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et à la prise en charge des dépenses de la famille.
Elles ambitionnent d’acheter du matériel agricole.
texts.en:
This group is composed of one single woman, two widows and five married women. The members of the group Badegna live mostly in monogamous families. On average they are 39 years old, each have 4 children and live in the center of the rural commune of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) The women in this group have businesses selling various products, running restaurants and creating food products. Having fully repaid their first loan, they are requesting theirs second group loan. With this new loan they will purchase: 4 sacks of rice, 7 sacks of corn, 3 sacks of fresh onions, 5 cartons of laundry soap, 1 sack of the local "Kabacourouni" brand soap, 6 sacks of charcoal, 2 loads of firewood, 3 sets of wax "pagnes" (colorful wax cloth), 4 sets of fancy "pagnes" (colorful wax cloth), 4 dozen pairs of shoes, 4 sacks of wheat flour, 2 twenty liter barrels of cooking oil and 48 empty bottles. They will purchase their supplies in Bamako (clothes and shoes), in Segou (rice, flour, onions, oil and bottles), and in Cinzana Gare for other merchandise. They will sell their wares in Cinzana's market and from their homes, for cash and credit. Their clientele is composed of men and women. They hope to earn an average monthly income of 19,125 FCFA, which they will use to repay the interest on their loan and take care of family expenses. Their ambition is to purchase farming equipment.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products

loans.name: Mahamatmuso

texts.en:
Mahamatmuso A. is 28 years old. He is married with two children. Eleven years ago Mahamatmuso decided to start his own business selling carpet. Since he had always wanted to be an entrepreneur, Mahamatmuso began his business with his hard earned savings. He is familiar with the business and provides good customer service. He has many clients and his business keeps growing. In order to satisfy the high demand, he now needs a loan in the amount of $3000 USD which he will use to purchase more inventory. Be a part of this business and of Mahamatmuso's family by supporting his growing business, they greatly appreciate it!

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: M. Jane is a promising business lady of 28 years old, married with 3 children. She sells clothes and she has been running her business for over 5 years. She is using the loan to purchase clothing such as dresses, skirts, blouses, and so forth for sale. She hopes for business improvement. Her future plan is to work very hard and establish another boutique.

loans.use: To purchase clothes such as dresses, skirts, blouses, and so forth for sale

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est composé de six femmes mariées dans des ménages monogames ayant en moyenne 30 ans, 5 enfants et habitant le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du Mali).  
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités professionnelles.
Elles font le commerce d’articles  divers, la fabrication de la bière locale, de la restauration etc. Elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt de groupe, après avoir correctement  remboursé le premier prêt. 
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 sacs de riz, 9 sacs de mil, 12 sacs de patates douces, 1 bidon de 30 litres d’huile, 6 cartons d’Omo, 1sac de sucre, 1carton de thé,  2  chargements de charrettes  en  bois de chauffe et des bouteilles vides. 
Leurs marchandises sont achetées à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare, exceptés le bois de chauffe et les bouteilles vides dans lesquelles on y met de la bière locale le  « dolo ». 
Pour préparer la bière locale, le mil est lavé et gardé humide jusqu’à sa germination puis il est étalé au soleil avant d’être moulu et cuit des heures ensuite, on y ajoute un peu de poudre de feuilles de baobab à la cuisson; il est filtré et fermenté pendant 2 à 3 jours pour être vendu. Une partie de la patate est frite avant sa vente. 
La vente des marchandises se fait au marché et à  domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, la contribution à la  prise en charges de certaines dépenses familiales et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions et funérailles). 
Leurs ambitions se résument à l’augmentation du montant de leurs prêts, leur permettant une diversification des activités.
texts.en:
The group Djiguiya is composed of six married women of monogamous households who average 30 years of age and five children living in the chief locale of the rural community of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of kinship and their professional work.  They do commerce in various goods, make the local beer, and work in food catering.  The group members are on their second group loan after having correctly repaid the first one.  This new loan will be used to buy:  two sacks of rice, nine sacks of millet, twelves sacks of potatoes, a 30-liter container of oil, six boxes of Omo detergent, a sack of sugar, a box of tea, two cart-loads of firewood, and some empty bottles. Their goods are purchased at the Cinzana Gare weekly fair, except for the firewood and the empty bottles, which are filled with dolo, the local beer.  To make the local beer, you wash the millet and keep it moist until it germinates.  Then you spread it out under the sun.  After a few hours, you mill it and cook it.  A little baobab leaf powder is added during the cooking.  You filter and then ferment it for two to three days before selling it. A portion of the potatoes is fried and then sold.  The goods are sold at the marketplace and in homes.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women.  The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 20,500 francs CFA that will be used to cover the loan interest, to help with certain family expenses, and to take part in societal events (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals).  Their ambition comes down to increasing the loan amounts borrowed, enabling them to diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Tanutsu Women Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Tanutsu Women' group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to request a loan in order to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

Aminata K. (second from left) is 35 years old. She was born in Makeni and is married to a businessman. The two of them have 3 children – one in secondary school and two in primary school. Aminata sells margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, sugar, etc. She has been a businesswoman for many years. With her share of the loan, she will buy packets of margi, bags of salt, and bags of sugar.

loans.use: Buy packets of margi, bags of salt, and bags of sugar

loans.name: Sadbarg

texts.en:
A. Sadbarg is a happy mother of three children. She is 34 years old and married. Sadbarg is a teacher. Her salary is very little and that’s why she has been running her own grocery business. For 15 years she has been selling foodstuffs such as: baby food, sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and many others in her grocery store.

Sadbarg’s wish is to increase her business, offering various types of foodstuffs to her customers who pass through this market. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are all the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts. With this opportunity and with the immense love she feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni in order to increase the range of her goods. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting Sadbarg.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Tukhtabibi

texts.en:
A. Tukhtabibi is 36 years old; she lives with her spouse and works every day starting very early in the morning so that she can get ahead and achieve her goal of having her 3 children successfully finish school and enter university. Her business is located in the central market of Tursunzade town and she sells clothes for women.

Thanks to the support of her spouse and her own efforts, Tukhtabibi was able to expand her business, which began with little inventory and in a small space and now has a bigger space and a large clientele. With the loan of 4000 Somoni, she will buy a greater variety of clothing styles, for a variety of occasions, and a few specific requests for her customers. Support this woman of much strength and courage so she can keep working!

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for women in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Sinignèssigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèssigui est composé de quatre femmes, une veuve, et trois mariées dans des ménages polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans,  4 enfants et habitent le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, de leurs activités commerciales  et d’appartenance à une même association des femmes de Cinzana Gare.
Ce groupe de femmes s’est vraiment spécialisé dans la restauration qui constitue leur activité principale.
 Elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire, avoir correctement  remboursé leur  premier prêt.  
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 sacs de riz, 2 sacs de mil, 2 sacs de farine de blé, 1 bidon d’huile de 20 litres, 30 sachets de spaghettis et des condiments  nécessaires à la préparation de différents plats alimentaires. 
Toutes leurs marchandises sont achetées sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare. Toutes ces denrées alimentaires sont  destinées à la restauration. 
Le mil est pilé, dépourvu du son soigneusement lavé et réduit en farine fine pour faire des gâteaux à la vapeur. Pour les obtenir on ajoute un peu de farine de blé à la fine farine de mil, bien mélangée ; mettre du sucre, du sel et un peu de levure et avec de l’eau, malaxer ce mélange jusqu’à obtenir une pâte homogène ; la fermer hermétiquement pendant au moins une heure de temps ; la malaxer de nouveau et la mettre en petites boules de cinq et faire cuire à la vapeur à l’aide d’un canaris percé ainsi on obtient nos gâteaux de mil appelés « takoula ».  
La vente se fait au marché de Cinzana Gare et surtout à la foire hebdomadaire et à domicile. Le « takoula » se vend  devant les mosquées les vendredis ou sur commande. Une partie de la farine de blé est frite avant de la vendre. Les ventes se font au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 13.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, à l’achat de nourriture et à la participation aux évènements sociaux. 
Leur principale ambition est la diversification de leur activité en embrassant l’élevage de petits  ruminants.
texts.en:
The group Sinignèssigui is composed of four women (one widowed and three married) in polygamous households.  The women average 38 years of age and four children each living in the chief locale of the rural community of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of community, kinship, their commercial businesses, and from belonging to the same women's association of Cinzana Gare.  This group of women truly became specialized in food service, which constitutes their main work.  The group members are on their second solidarity loan after having properly repaid their first one.  This new loan will be used to buy: two sacks of rice, two sacks of millet, two sacks of wheat flour, a 20-liter container of oil, thirty pouches of spaghetti, and some condiments necessary for cooking various dishes.  All of their goods are purchased locally at the Cinzana Gare weekly fair.  These groceries are all destined for food catering.  The millet is pounded, freed of its bran, washed gently, and then milled into a fine flour for making steamed cakes.  To make them, you add a little wheat flour to the fine millet flour and mix well;  add some sugar, salt, and a little leavening with water; knead this mixture until obtaining a uniform dough;  seal it up tightly for at least an hour;  knead it again, and roll it into five-centimeter balls.  Then you steam them using a pierced canaris (terra cotta vessel).  This is how you make our millet cakes called takoula.  Sales of the goods are carried out at the Cinzana Gare marketplace and especially at the weekly fair and at home.  The takoula is sold in front of mosques on Fridays or by special order.  A portion of the wheat flour is fried and then sold.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women.  The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 13,500 francs CFA that will be used to cover the loan interest, to buy food, and to take part in societal events.  Their main ambition is to diversify their business by taking up the raising of small ruminants. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: K. Patrick is a businessman of thirty-one years old. He is married with five children going to school. He deals in supplying hardware products. He has been in this business for over 3 years. He is using the loan to add capital in order to purchase a big stock of  cement and so forth for his business. His future plans are to expand the business, educate his children, and give good care to his family.

loans.use: purchasing big stocks of cement and so forth for his business

loans.name: Safarmo

texts.ru: Худойдодова Сафармо проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 35 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Худойдодова Сафармо имеет среднее образование. Она работает в месте с мужем более 4 лет. Они изготавливают и продают свою продукцию. Кредит берет для закупа песка и цемента.
texts.en:
K. Safarno lives in the city of Kulob. She's thirty-five years old, married, has five children and a high school education. She has been working with her husband, manufacturing and selling products, for more than four years. She's asking for a loan in order to buy sand and cement.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sand and cement

loans.name: One Family Group

texts.en:
Eyee G. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'One Family'. She is married with 2 children aged 10 and 23 years old; their educational levels are 3rd and 12th grade. She also cares for 2 nieces. She did not go to school herself due to poverty.

Eyee and her family live and work in the Jacob Town community in Gardnerville, Monrovia, Liberia but she sell in the Red-light market which is the biggest market in Liberia in Paynesville.

Eyee’s business is the sale of alcoholic beverages such as hard cane juice and locally-made gin. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail in a small shop in the Jacob Town community. She has been running this business for more than 12 years and hopes to own a rice store in the near future.

Eyee started selling with 2000 Liberian Dollars that she raised from her petty trade business. She is friendly towards her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Eyee needs this loan to purchase more alcoholic beverages for resale. She dreams of giving her children a good education so they will have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Eyee is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more alcoholic beverages for resale

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: K. Samuel is a businessman of forty-one years old, married with four children. He owns a drug shop; he has been operating this drug shop for over two years. He is using the loan to purchase drugs in variety. He is purchasing different medicines to cater for customers' needs. His future plan is opening up a clinic to cater for patients.

loans.use: To purchase drugs in variety

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Women In Unity Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Women in Unity' group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 2,500,000 in order to expand their businesses.

The leader of this group of 4 is Fudia K.. Fudia is 35 years old and married to a businessman and they have 6 children – 2 in primary school and 4 in secondary school. Fudia sells palm oil and has been in this business for many years. With the help of this loan, Fudia will buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business inventory

loans.name: God Can Make It Group

texts.en:
Rebecca G. W. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'God Can Make It'. She is 52 years old and is married with 2 children aged 18 and 30 years old; their educational levels are 10th grade and a high school graduate. She also cares for a nephew, a niece and a grandchild. She could not continue her education through 8th grade due poverty; she had to leave school to fend for her younger brothers, because their father had died.

Rebecca and her family live in the Zayzay community in Paynesville, but she sell in the Red-light market which is the biggest market in Paynesville, Liberia. Rebecca’s business is the sale of 'fufu' (a locally made Liberian dish of cassava). She has been running this business for more than 34 years and hopes to get involved in the real estate business.

Rebecca started by selling children's clothes and her capital, 1000 Liberian Dollars, was given to her by her husband. She sells clean 'fufu' and talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Rebecca needs this loan to add to her capital to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education and building a house for her family in the future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rebecca is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fufu for resale

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: S. Samson is a businessman of thirty-five years old; he is married with five children, all schooling. He owns a retail shop which he has been operating for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, soap, flour, rice, bread, drinks, and so forth for sale. He wishes to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, soap, flour, rice, bread, drinks, and so forth

loans.name: Cherryl

texts.en:
Cherryl E. is a 35-year old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy Andulawan Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fish vending, raising crabs and breeding oysters.

Cherryl’s husband Romel is a fishermen, and they have 5 children who are between 7 mos. and 14 years old. The older children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Cherryl E. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in  2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fish vending, fattening crabs and breeding oysters. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000 from her business activities.

Cherryl E. is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,500 was used to fund operations of her fish vending and crab-fattening, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her  16th loan, in the amount of Php 21,000, which she intends to use in her fish vending business. Cherryl E. is working hard to achieve her dreams and her aspiration for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia Q. is a 35-year old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by food vending, pig fattening and selling ice candy.

Alicia’s husband Pepito Q. helps his wife in running the businesses. They have 4 children who are between 10 mos and 16 years old. Three of their children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Alicia Q. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in food vending, pig fattening and ice candy business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 35,000 from her business activities.

Alicia Q. is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her food vending and ice candy, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 16th loan, in the amount of Php 19,000, which she intends to use on food vending, pig fattening and ice candy. Alicia Q. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspiration for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Nathan Douglas

texts.en: N. Nathan Douglas is a businessman who is 36 years old. He is married with five children. He owns a poultry farm and he has been carrying out this business for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase poultry drugs, poultry feeds and different breeds of chicks, such as layers and broilers. His future plan is to increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase poultry drugs, poultry feeds and chicks

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en: Mia N. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able Group. She is 47 years old and a single mother of four children. The children are aged 18 to 29 years old and their educational levels are 8th grade to high school graduate. She also cares for a friend’s daughter. She could not continue her education through 8th grade due to lack of financial support. Mia and her family live in the Red-light reservoir community in Paynesville, but she sells in the Red-light market, which is the biggest market in Paynesville, Liberia. Mia’s business is selling general goods such as soap, canned food, sugar, candles, etc. She buys general goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in the Red-light market. She has been running this business for more than nine years and hopes to becomes an importer of general merchandise in the near future. Mia started selling with 1000.00 Liberian Dollars that was raised from her father’s coffee farm. She arranges her goods in an organized way and talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Mia needs this loan to purchase more goods for resale. She dreams of building a house for her family in the future. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mia is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more goods, such as soap and canned food, for resale

loans.name: Princess

texts.en: Princess N. is a 34-year-old married woman who lives in Prk Paraiso Brgy Hilamonan, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in food vending. Princess's husband, Jonathan, earns his income by buying and selling household and car tools. They have four children who are between 7 and 15 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Princess N. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the food-vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of 12,000 Philippine pesos from her business activities. Princess N. is a member in good standing of NWTF-Project Dungganon, a Kiva partner. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her food-vending business. It had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing for her 17th loan the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use for her food-vending business. Princess N. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. loans.use: Additional working capital and to finance her husband's business

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros T. is a 53-year old married woman who lives in Brgy Binicuil Kabankalan City Negros Occidental. She earns her living by direct selling personal  & specialty products and RTW (Ready-to-Wear) Clothes.

Milagros and her husband Danilo have 3 children who are between 25 and 33 years old. Two children are already established with their own families. Milagros is quite proud that one of her children now works as a bookkeeper in the Toledo Branch of NWTF-Project Dunggganon in the island of Cebu.

Milaros joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1981 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in direct selling activities and RTW. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000 from her business activities.

Milagros is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her direct selling and RTW, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 7th loan for the amount of Php 17,000, which she intends to use on direct selling and RTW. Milagros is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Josamu

texts.en:
Josamu K. is a 31-year-old business man who is married and has two children. He owns a retail shop that he has been running for over three years.

Josamu is requesting a loan to purchase retail items such as rice, sugar, flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, eggs, soap, bread, and so forth to sell. His plan is to expand his business by increasing his stock.

loans.use: To purchase staples for his shop such as rice, flour, and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Mehman

texts.en:
Mehman B. is a 43-year-old café owner. He opened his café in 2001 offering tea but, little by little, he expanded his tea house to a café and now offers meat and chicken meals among with tea. His son helps him.

Now, Mehman needs 1,600 AZN to purchase new tables, chairs and dishes.

loans.use: To purchase new chairs, tables and dishes

loans.name: Daba

texts.fr: Daba T. est une femme de 56 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants en charge. Elle est membre be Banc Villageois depuis 5 ans et a eu de bonnes performances avec le crédit. Elle fait le commerce de tissu, une activité qui lui génère des bénéfices lui permettant de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Daba T. is a 56-year-old woman who is married and the mother of eight children to support. She has been a member of Banc Villageois for five years and has handled loans well. She does commerce in fabrics, a business that generates the profits that allow her to take part in covering family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering and developing her commercial business

loans.name: Khachatur

texts.en:
Khachatur B. is 50 years old and lives with his wife, Aida, in Nerqin Hand village in the Kapan area of Armenia. Khachatur is educated and is now Nerqin Hand’s mayor. His wife is a librarian who works in the village’s library. Khachatur and his wife operate a farm where they produce meat, milk, eggs and honey.

Khachatur has a caterpillar tractor (DT-75), a wheeled tractor (MT3-82) and a utility truck that he uses on his farm. He also rents these vehicles to people in the village. He is requesting a 700,000 AMD (Armenian dram) loan to buy a mowing machine for his farm.

loans.use: To buy a mowing machine for his farm.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia M. is a widow who supports her family by running a cafeteria and a general store and selling eggs. She lives in Mohon Brgy 1, Kabankalan City with her four children aged 25 to 32 years old. Three of her children already have their own families and one child works in Cebu City.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her cafeteria, general store and egg vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,500.

Ofelia M. is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can continue operating her cafeteria, general store and egg vending business. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ofelia M. aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena H. is 36 years old and married, and she is the loving mother of two children. Rena’s husband is currently unemployed, so her business is the main source of income for her family.

Rena has a grocery store where she sells sweets (candies), preserved food, juices, soft drinks, detergents, and other products. She has been in this business for five years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Rena is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her store to buy groceries again.

Rena wants to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 1,200 AZN to increase the inventory she has for sale. 

One of Rena’s dreams is that her daughters progress by means of their studies. You can help Rena to approach her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Rohnie

texts.en:
Rohnie T. is a 55-year old, married woman who lives in Brgy 2, Himamaylan City, Negros, Occidental. She earns her living by running a general store and selling rice.

Rohnie’s husband, Nemerio T., is helping his wife run the business. They have five children. The four older ones are already gainfully employed and only one is left in school. All the children do their part by helping their parents run the family business.

Rohnie T. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store and selling rice. Now she earns an average monthly income of P 50,000 from her business activities.

Rohnie T. is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 was used to fund operations of her general store and rice retailing business. It has had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing P 19,500 for her 11th loan, which she intends to use for her general store and rice retailing businesses. She also plans to buy a tricycle and a rice farm in the near future. Rohnie T. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Good Samaritan #3 Group

texts.en:
Kumba T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Good Samaritan #3. She is 40 years old and is married with three children aged 17-23 years old. They are in school in grades 6 through 12. She did not go to school due to poverty. Kumba and her family live in the Redlight Johnson compound community in Paynesville, but sell in the Redlight market, which is the biggest market in Liberia. The market is located in Paynesville, Liberia. Kumba’s sells general goods like oil, candles, milk, and bananas, etc. She buys the generals goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia.  She has been running this business for more than 20 years and hopes to own a general goods store. Kumba started selling with 2,000 Liberian Dollars, given to her by her husband. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Kumba needs this loan to purchase more general goods to sell. She dreams of giving her children and grandchildren a good education for a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kumba is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

texts.en:
Rovelyn H. is a 27-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Mohon Brgy 1, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running an eatery.

Rovelyn’s husband, Richard, is helping his wife run the eatery business. They have two children who are three and five years old. They strive hard to prepare for the future of their children, hoping to provide them with a good education and a comfortable life.

Rovelyn H. is a member in good standing. Now she is borrowing PHP 10,000 for her fourth loan. She intends to use the loan on her eatery business. Rovelyn H. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Bebsy

texts.en:
Bebsy O. is a 33-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying and selling Ready-to-Wear (RTW) clothes and herbal medicines.

Bebsy’s husband, Pedro O. Jr., works as a driver and an electrician. The couple has no children, but Bebsy still strives hard to improve the quality of life of her family, including her parents and brothers.

Bebsy O. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. Bebsy O. is a member in good standing. Bebsy O. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Kujang

texts.en:
Kujang M. is currently in the business of selling beer and sodas. She is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell.  Kujang is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Karine

texts.en: Karine N. was born in 1967 in Kirovabad town in Azerbaijan. She is not married. Karine has a high education and she is a pharmaceutical chemist. In 1988, during the Armenian and Azerbaijan conflict, Karine and her mother transmigrated to Yerevan, where they lived as refugees. Now they are competent citizens of the Republic of Armenia and live in their own apartment in Yerevan. Karine started her own trade business about 10 years ago. Four times a month Karine goes to Turkey and imports clothes for her store in the Ararat trade center. Karine needs a $1500 loan to buy new shirts, trousers, suits, coats and perfumes to sell.

She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business and build a house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.en:
Halima K. is currently in the business of selling onions and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock beans and cooking oil to sell.  Halima is 28 years old and is married to a businessman. She has eight children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rental house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock beans and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Ramatoulaye

texts.fr: Ramatoulaye D. est une femme de 39 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois WALIDANE depuis 5 ans et a eu 10 expériences avec le crédit. Elle vend des tissus teintés. Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et de contribuer aux différentes charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ramatoulaye D. is a 39-year-old woman who is married and the mother of three.  She has been a member of Banc Villageois de WALIDANE for five years and had ten experiences with loans.  Ramatoulaye sells dyed cloth.  Her goal is to bolster her savings and to help cover various family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering and developing her commercial work

loans.name: Buta

texts.en:
Buta E. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, sim sim (sesame seeds) and other products, and is requesting a loan to purchase dried cassava flour to sell.  Buta is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has eight children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase dried cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María V. S. tiene 61 años y vive en el barrio Martínez Martelo de Cartagena, ciudad colonial y turística del Caribe Latino, de clima soleado y playas con aguas cálidas. Se siente muy orgullosa de su barrio  pues es uno de los más antiguos de Cartagena y queda circundado por una de las bahías mas lindas del mundo, la bahía de Cartagena y cercano a un mercado de alimentos y productos variados, el mercado de Bazurto, zona de gran afluencia comercial de la cual se aprovisiona.
María Inició su negocio de manera incipiente  con una fotocopiadora, desde este local se dedicaba a la   venta de seguros obligatorios de accidentes de transito (SOAT) por intermedio  de una compañía aseguradora; lo que pronto la hizo muy reconocida en la plaza de este mercado que día a día solicitaba otros servicios como el de laminar documentos, que la llevaron a adquirir  una laminadora dándole respuesta a las necesidades de sus mimados clientes;  Con todo esto María se sentía  muy entusiasmada con su negocio pues  observó día a día como  su clientela aumentaba y  una vez mas requerían de ella otros servicios como el de telefonía, lo que la condujo a acceder a dos amplios planes de telefonía celular para que sus clientes pudieran efectuar llamadas a destinos locales, nacionales e internacionales. Su experiencia la ha llevado a escuchar la voz del cliente, por esta razón una de sus metas principales es la de comprar un cubetero con capacidad de 500 cubetas ya que en su negocio hay una gran demanda de refrescos.  
En la actualidad requiere un financiamiento por valor de  $1.500.000 para invertirlo en  la compra de insumos para la fotocopiadora como papelería y tinta, acceder a amplios planes de telefonía celular y comprar mercancía  variada, aprovechando su infraestructura y la capacidad comercial de su ubicación. María cuenta con su hijo de 40 años de edad y esta feliz de tener un local comercial en la ciudad de Cartagena de Indias.
texts.en:
María is 61 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Martínez Martelo in Cartegena, which is a colonial city and a tourist destination on the Caribbean coast. The city has a sunny climate and beaches with warm water. She feels great pride in her neighborhood as it is one of the oldest in Cartegena and is surrounded by one of the most beautiful bays in the world, Cartegena Bay, and close to a market that sells foods and various other goods, the Bazurto market, which is an area of great commercial activity which is well stocked-up.

María started her business in a small way with a photocopier, since this area specializes in the sale of a special type of insurance for travel accidents through the medium of an insurance company. She immediately made herself well-know in the market where people asked her for other related services, such as laminating documents. So, she added a laminator to her business, allowing her to respond to the needs of her well-served clients. With all this, María feels very enthusiastic about her business, and she has seen her cliental grow day by day and once again ask her for new services such as telephone service. So she added two comprehensive cell phone plans so that her clients can call locally, nationally, and internationally. Her experience has taught her to listen to her clients, and for this reason it is one of her main goals to buy a fridge with 500 unit capacity since their is a great demand for soft drinks in her business premises.

At this moment, she needs a loan of $1,500 to buy supplies for the photocopier such as paper and ink, subscribe to cell phone plans, and to buy various merchandise, thus taking advantage of the infrastructure and capacity of her location. María has a son who is 40 years old, and she is happy to have a business in the city of Cartegena.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy photocoper supplies, subscribe to cell phone plans, and buy various merchandise

loans.name: Nora Elena

texts.es:
Nora Elena García B. tiene 33 años de edad, vive en el tradicional barrio Olaya Herrera de Cartagena, es oriunda de San Juan de Nepomuceno, municipio del departamento de Bolívar, que en algún momento golpeado por la inseguridad, la violencia y desplazamiento forzado, obligaron a Nora a huir de esta zona de conflictos desde hace 5 años hacia la ciudad de Cartagena, en compañía de sus 3 hijos de 9, 7 y 2 años y de su esposo, quien dedicado a las labores del campo no encontró trabajo digno en la ciudad; así fuè como ella asumió la responsabilidad del sustento de su hogar, practicando los conocimientos de costura que aprendió desde muy niña y que con la ayuda de una generosa pareja que le donó una máquina de coser, pudo iniciar muy entusiasmada el negocio de confecciones que hoy tiene y con el que sueña verlo crecer y ayudarla a su prosperidad familiar, para lo cual dirige todos sus esfuerzos.   
 
Nora se siente satisfecha de la vida, da gracias a Dios diariamente por estar viva y reafirma el proverbio que dice no hay mal que por bien no venga, porque con el desplazamiento ella encontró la oportunidad de tener un mejor futuro en otra tierra, que  quizás no hubiera logrado en el lugar que la vio nacer. 

En su negocio llamado “Confecciones Angie”, compra telas e insumos de bajo costo y elabora vestidos económicos, ella dice que con ello contribuye a aliviar la problemática de capacidad de compra que tienen las personas que viven en su barrio y sus alrededores, pues “sus clientes se sientan muy satisfechos al poder estrenar un vestido nuevo”. 
Su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, fue por valor de $1.500.000 que reembolsó estrictamente de acuerdo a su plan de amortización, pues lo invirtió en mercancías y variedades que le ayudaron a obtener una buena utilidad para poder adquirir nuevos electrodomésticos y utensilios  para su hogar que aun no poseía; en la actualidad aplica a un crédito por valor de $2.000.000, que invertirá en la compra de materia prima e insumos para la confección de ropa, en comprar calzado y vestidos infantiles para surtir su vitrina y en adquirir una maquina de cocer nueva,  pues además de confeccionar  también vende mercancía en su barrio.

Su máximo sueño es obtener una vivienda y un local para organizar y expandir su negocio logrando adquirir tecnología de punta  y  posicionarse en el mercado ofreciendo muchos puestos de trabajo y logrando dividendos que le ayuden al crecimiento humano, espiritual, profesional, de sus hijos y de sus futuros empleados. 

Su desafió actual es la falta de maquinaria adecuada para hacer un trabajo de mejor calidad  y recibir capacitación y  en unión de su esposo y de su familia emprender el montaje  y desarrollo de una gran empresa de confecciones.
texts.en:
Nora Elena García B. is 33 years old and lives in the traditional neighborhood Olaya Herrera in Cartagena. She is a native of the town of San Juan de Nepomuceno in the department of Bolívar, which at the this moment has been hit with insecurity, violence and forced displacement, requiring Nora to flee this conflict area 5 years ago to the city of Cartagena. She fled along with her 3 children of 9,7,and 2 years and her husband, who works in the countryside since he could not find decent work in the city. It was thus that she assumed the responsibility of supporting the household, practicing her trade as a seamstress that she learned when she was very young. With the help of a generous couple who gave her a sewing machine she was able to start, with great enthusiasm, the business that she has today. She hopes to see this business grow and help her family become more prosperous, and she directs all of her efforts toward these goals. She feels satisfied with her life, and gives thanks to God daily for being alive. She reaffirms the saying that every cloud has a silver lining, because with the displacement she found the opportunity to have a better future in a different place, which perhaps she might not have had in the place where she was born. In her business, called "Confecciones Angie" (Creations by Angie), she buys fabrics and supplies at low cost and makes economical dresses. She says that with this business she helps alleviate the problem that people have in her neighborhood of not having enough money to buy new clothing, and says that "her customers feel very satisfied being able to wear a new dress for the first time." Her first loan with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation was for $1,500, which she paid back strictly according to the established schedule. She invested it in a variety of merchandise that helped her to obtain greater profits, which enabled her to acquire new household appliances and utensils that she did not yet have. She is now applying for a loan of $2,000 that she will use to buy raw materials and supplies to make clothing, to buy shoes and baby clothes to put on sale in her glass display case, and to acquire a new sewing machine, because in addition to making clothes she also sells merchandise in her neighborhood. Her greatest dream is to have a home and a place to organize and expand her business, managing to acquire state-of-the-art technology and positioning herself in the market offering many jobs and generating profits to help the human, spiritual and professional growth of her children and future employees. Her current challenge is that she lacks the adequate training and machinery to do work of the best quality and to start, along with her husband and his family, to set up and develop a large apparel company.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy raw materials and supplies to make clothing, to buy shoes and baby clothes to sell, and to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Sadia

texts.en:
Sadia M. is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Sadia is 32 years old and is married to a driver. She has five children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nyongle

texts.en:
Nyongle V. is currently in the business of selling fresh cabbages and Irish potatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  Nyongle is 29 years old and married to a builder. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC, a Kiva partner, has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

 In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: We Are Not Alone Group

texts.en: Mark's business is selling an array of general goods such as cigarettes, soap, mosquito coils, hard cane juice and palm wine. He sells from a table in Jacobs Town, which is near the Red Light market area. Red Light is Liberia's largest market, about 5 miles from the capital, Monrovia. It is a bustling area full of shops, stalls, and vendor tables. He says his success in business will "depend on the capital I have." Mark plans to use the 6,000 Liberian dollars he will get as a part of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to expand the inventory he offers at his shop. Mark is a high school graduate and is currently attending the University of Liberia as a second-year economics major. If he can afford to continue to pay tuition and other expenses, he hopes to graduate from university in two years' time. Mark says when he finished school he wants to get a job with the Liberian government, the United Nations or a private firm. Mark is 35 years old and single. He has two daughters with his ex-girlfriend and he helps to support them. His three-year-old daughter lives with his ex-girlfriend in Monrovia and his seven-year-old daughter lives and works on his parent's farm in rural Lofa County. We Are Not Alone is a group of five borrowers led by Mark L. that live and work near Red Light, Paynesville. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mark is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a general store, such as cigarettes, soap, mosquito coils, hard cane juice and palm wine

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa N. est une femme de 40 ans, elle mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont les 3 lui sont confiés. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle fait de la restauration, elle sert le repas  dans son quartier au tour d'une table. Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille et de renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
Awa N. is a 40-year-old woman who is married and the mother of four children.  Three of them are entrusted to her.  She has been a member of Banc Villageois de WALIDANE for 3½ years.  She works in food service.  She serves meals in her district from a table.  Her goal is to take part in covering family expenses and to bolster her savings. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering and developing her business

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.fr: Sokhna S. est âgée de 43 ans, elle mariée et mère de 4 enfants. elle est membre du Banc Villageois de PALENE depuis 3 ans et a eu à y bénéficier de 6 prêts qu'elle à bien gérés et remboursés. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine et ovine. Son objectif est de participer aux différentes charge familiale et de renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
Sokhna S. is 43 years old, married, and the mother of four children.  For three years, she has been a member of Banc Villageois de PALENE, where she has benefited from six loans, which she managed well and repaid.  Sokhna fattens cows and sheep.  Her goal is to help cover various family expenses and to boost her savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Advancing her business

loans.name: Cora Maurelina

texts.es: Cora Maurelina labora en la escuela Miguel Lareynaga como docente en colonia El Serrano, estudia en la universidad URACCAN para prepararse mejor e impartir sus conocimientos a los niños de su comunidad. Ademas realiza actividades agricola y ganadera, en coordinación con su marido y su papá que le brindan su apoyo. Cora Maurelina está solicitando  a AFODENIC, su primer crèdito para la compra de una computadora con sus accesorios, con el objetivo de equipamiento de un medio de trabajo, pues adquirir este equipo le ayudaria en gran manera la realizacion de los materiales que utilizaria para impartir sus clases,  ya que en esta comunidad no hay acceso a estos equipo, Cora es una joven con muchos deseos de superaciòn, con buenas costumbres, honesta y responsable.
texts.en:
Cora Maurelina works as a teacher in the school Miguel Lareynaga, in the district of El Serrano. She is studying at the university URACCAN in order to better prepare herself and impart her knowledge to the children in her community. Additonally, she works with agriculture and livestock, in coordination with her husband and her father who provide her with support. Cora Maurelina is requesting her first credit from AFODENIC in order to purchase a computer with accessories, because acquiring this equipment would help her in a great way for giving her classes, since in her community there is no access to such equipment. Cora is a young woman with a lot of desire to get ahead and good habits, as well as being honest and responsible.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a computer

loans.name: Epefania Puyod's Group

texts.en: Epefania P.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. Aside from the snack business, she also has other sources of income such as farming and raising pigs. She is 60 years old, married and has five grown up children. She is from the village of Tubod. Epefania has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2002, Epefania joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Epefania has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Epefania is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase inventory and for working capital. This will be her 14th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. Epefania is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Mercedes Del Carmen

texts.es:
Mercedes R. de 44 años de edad, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, tiene en su casa con agua y luz como servicios básicos, su esposo trabaja haciendo ladrillos con el tiene 4 hijas ya todos son mayores de edad. 
 
Mercedes empezó vendiendo verduras poco a poco pudo implementar productos comestibles. Cuando ya obtuvo ingresos necesarios se cambio a un local más grande. Ahora ella trabaja con sus hijas de lunes a domingos vendiendo arroz, azúcar, colas, legumbres, etc. Uno de los inconvenientes que tienen es la transportación de la mercadería a la tienda.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, verduras, azúcar, colas para incrementar más su tienda. En el futuro quiere comprarse una camioneta para poder transportar la mercadería y poder construir mejor su casa.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 44 years old and lives in a suburb of Paraíso de Guayaquil. She has basic services in her home, such as water and electricity. Her husband is a brick maker. She has had four daughters with her husband, and they are all adults.

Mercedes began selling vegetables and little by little added other edible goods. When she has enough savings, she will move to larger premises. She now works Monday through Sunday with her daughters, selling rice, sugar, soft drinks, vegetables, etc. One of the inconveniences that she faces is transporting the merchandise to her shop.
